text:
I was pretty excited to find this recipe - my favorite cafe' makes these humongous crinkles that are so dark they're black! But sadly, although these were pretty good, they were not like the ones at the cafe'. I give it 4 stars because they were fudgy and had a good flavor and everyone liked them, but they just weren't the ones I was hoping for. A note about working with the sticky dough - I'm glad I read other reviews. I put mine in the freezer for about 45 minutes and used spoons to scoop out the dough DIRECTLY into the powdered sugar. Once the dough was in the sugar, they were easy to handle and just plopped into a perfect circle onto the pan. And you MUST used GREASED pans or they WILL stick terribly because of the powdered sugar on the bottom of the cookie.

text:
These are my childhood favorite.  I make them every christmas.  Thing is I'm lazy, so i created a different recipe with the same dough, so i get two types of cookies for the same work.  Instead of rolling them in powdered sugar, i roll some in regular granulated sugar and then after they come out of the oven, i pop a hershey hug on top.  they're pretty and again, two cookies with the effort of one.  no one even recognizes they're the same. easy peasy

text:
This is a yummy-foolproof cookie recipe.  To intensify the chocolate "experience," I added 1/2 cup melted bittersweet chocolate and used dutch-processed cocoa powder.  For those who are having trouble with the top cracking, here's a tip:  Place your cookie sheet on the second to-the-top rack and only bake one cookie sheet at a time.  The hot heat at the top of the oven enables the cookie to crack.  This trick also works for ginger snaps.

None
text:
I've made these so many times and they always turn out! Make sure to coat them with enough powdered sugar to get them to "crinkle."

Here are some suggestions: Divide the dough into two and spread it out in a plate. Put it in the freezer for 30-45 minutes. Before forming them into balls, get your hands wet so they won't stick to them. You might have to pop them back in the freezer if it's a hot day just DON'T try to handle them when they're warm because you will just be wasting your time. Also, get creative with them! I've made them with cinnamon one time and I coated them with powdered sugar mixed with cinnamon and those turned out GREAT :)

This is a very good recipe. I'm so glad I found it. Since parchment paper is way too valuable in my kitchen for so many cookies, I find a light oiling of the cookie sheet works better for me. The cookies come off much easier than the parchment paper.

text:
These cookies were a delight to make.  They were simple, moist and delicious.  Doubling the recipe and using a 1 Tablespoon measure per cookie, I yielded about 80 cookies.  As a side note:  I noticed that a few people had troubles with getting these cookies to "crinkle".  Therefore, I made sure to coat them with enough powdered sugar and then baked them for the full time indicated to ensure a good "crinkle". They turned out perfectly.  I hope this helps!  Enjoy!

text:
This is one of the few recipes I would give a 10 if I could.. chewy, moist brownie type cookie.. Dont be fooled and let them bake 10 minutes, they will look done before, but learn from my mistake. I took them out at 8 minutes and they were raw in the middle. So 10 minutes does the trick! I have 2 things to say: one is i cant imagine why these dont "crinkle" for some people, its impossible for them not to crinkle, because as they spread the sugar spreads and well, they will crinkle! LOL. And 2, after spraying the sheet and using parchment paper i learned whats important is to transfer these to a wire rack after one minute.. NO MORE THAN 2 MINUTES! as they cool they will stick to whatever they are on!. good luck!

text:
This is by far the best cookie recipe I've ever made and for many, many reasons. All the ingredients are things I already have laying around. It's a very simple recipe, the steps are pretty basic. But the kicker is the versatility! I have made the recipe as-written several times and each time they are spectacular. Other variations: roll the dough in dark chocolate cocoa powder instead of confectioner's sugar then drizzle icing in a pretty pattern once they've cooled.. very chic looking. I've also rolled them in granulated sugar and then popped a frozen Hershey's Candy Cane Hug (OMG.. this is incredible.. the mint and chocolate and creaminess.. just OMG). Play around with the recipe! Thank you so much for sharing this!!

These tasted just like a brownie to me- chewy, moist and fudgy; delicious!  My three year old daughter helped roll them in sugar and we both had fun.  I used half whole-wheat pastry flour but kept everything else the same.  Used a cookie scoop to "roll" them and got only 3 dozen.  Took another reviewer's advice and used the second from the top oven rack, and they turned out crinkly and beautiful.

text:
These are delicious, rich cookies that remind me of tiny brownies. I have been making these cookies for years, every Christmas. These are like mini fudgy brownies, and I always make this dough the day before I plan to bake these. I found that the more chilled/cold the dough is, the easier it is to roll in balls, and since I heavily coat these with the powdered sugar, they are beautiful after baking. The sugar doesn't absorb into the cookie at all. Be sure to use the parchment paper too, it really makes a difference. Everyone loves these :)

text:
Should be called "Brownie Crinkles." Used canola oil and added 1/2 tsp soda to alkalize the acidity of the Hershey's cocoa - would not add soda if using Dutch cocoa, as it is already alkalized. Baked for 10 minutes exactly and texture was like fudgy, mini brownies. Added 1 cup chopped white chocolate. Excellent in every way!

text:
This is a great recipe.  Keep the dough refrigerated and take out only enough to workwith.  I found that once the dough gets warm it gets quite sticky and the cookies don't hold their shape well when baked.  The cooler the dough is while shaping the nicer the cookies look when baked.  I used a melon baller for size.

These cookies are chewy, chocolatey goodness.  The ONLY reason I gave them 4 stars instead of 5 is because I was hoping for a thicker cookie.  They baked fairly thin and I was hoping for something like my grandma used to make that was thicker.  I did put the dough in the freezer for a little while before scooping with my smallest ice cream scoop and dropping directly into the powdered sugar.  Then I didn't have a gooey mess on my hands.  Very yummy cookie over all just wish they were thicker.

text:
amazing cookies! I made these yesterday for a party, and was asked for the recipe. I followed the recipe exactly, except I didn't have time to let them chill for 4 hours. Instead I placed half the dough into the freezer for 45 mins-1 hour, and made those for the party. The other half went into the fridge and I baked them today--no difference in the two, both are delicious and look beautiful! I ended up with about 4 dozen total.

soooooo deliciously good. I wish I hadn't halved the recipe now. I might just have to make another batch. They taste like little brownie bites. userID:
4963532
Display Name:
IamNOTa scientist
isPro:
False

0

0

10

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5253740.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:

text:
First time poster here. I will start by saying that I've always wanted a (insert obvious brand name) mixer. After some personal struggle over the last couple of years, I was finally in a position to purchase said mixer. This was the first recipe made with this magical machine. 

Anyhoo...




I am an experienced baker. But I still follow directions with unfamiliar recipes. As I did in this case. To the letter. Carefully following the recipe, I made what looked more like a thick batter. Similar to how my brownie batter used to look (and taste for that matter). I made the cookie dough the night before, so I assumed it would set up. The next day I pulled the bowl out of the fridge and behold! it had firmed up quite nicely.

If you don't have a cookie scoop get one. This dough was so scoopable. You can find online for a lot cheaper than the kitchen gadget places sell them for. 

I scooped a few balls into some icing sugar and was surprised and how much sugar adhered. You can knock some off if you want, but the dough itself isn't that sweet, so the added sweetness the sugar brings to the finished product is nice. 

From here on out, slap 'em on a cookie sheet and bake. They come out exactly the way they are shown in the pics I've seen. Really nice presentation with the cracked surface.  

And they taste fantastic. Real nice heavy hit of chocolate in a nice very soft almost chewy consistency / texture. And they stay that way for a solid few days. Two words Yuh Mee.
Review:

5

text:
My mom has had this recipe for years, and I'd never made it.  I'd always made them using boxed cake mix, but hated all the chemicals.  These are SO good!  I made them for a huge family holiday party, and they were gone right away, with lots of compliments.  If you chill them overnight, and then "flour" your hands with powdered sugar, they aren't overly sticky.  Take them out of the oven when just the edges are set, and let them sit on the pan to finish for a minute or so.  DO NOT bake them through in the oven, or they will be overdone.  No boxed mix cookies for me anymore.  Wish I'd used my mom's recipe years ago!

I saved these months ago when they were featured on the front page to make for Christmas. The cookies looked beautiful.. just like the picture! However, they were an absolute PAIN to make. After only a couple of minutes, they were turning to complete goo. They were almost impossible to roll. If I were to make again (which I won't), I would freeze the batter/dough before rolling. It might help it stay manageable longer. I do it with my peanut butter cookies every year with much success.

text:
I DON'T bake,  so when I try to make cookies from scratch it better be simple.... this recipe was great! I made them for Christmas Eve.  got the mix done, chilled for about 3 hrs and baked perfectly with very little effort.  I used an ice cream scooper and rolled them into semi-tight little balls and didn't have a problem with too much sticking.  you just gotta roll fast and plop into sugar. 

I this used those large foil type cookie trays (the dollar store type) so I can't speak on the need to grease the sheet,  I didn't and they slid off without a spatula.  I baked them on the second from top rack for 11 min.  

every one loved them and I have some picky people here.  I'd say they are like a cookie/brownie.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2125626.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As per some reviews, this batter is on the thin side, but after refridgerating it's not bad. The dough is sticky and hard to handle with a scoop. Definately use parchment paper to save yourself clean up. I baked these more like 15-17 min. Touch the top lightly before you take out of the oven. If it still feels soft and like its not done, add like 3 more minutes. I also had to let these rest on the sheet after taking out of the oven, so they wouldn't come apart upon transferring to a cooling rack. As far as flavor,and moistness they're pretty good, but they flatten out upon baking, they don't look like the pic. I'll probably look for a better recipe in the future of chocolate crinkle cookie baking.

text:
What a marvelous little recipe!  I've never made these before & wasn't sure what to expect.  To me they are a round, snowy brownie. After cooling, I dropped the individual spoonfuls of dough directly onto a saucer of icing sugar.  Then I dusted my palms with icing sugar when I rolled them to keep from sticking & heating up in my hands.  Worked perfectly! Off to a cookie exchange tomorrow, happily taking my Crinkles. Thanks Ingrid.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My tips- don't skimp on the confectioners sugar. And roll them around good to make the sugar stick.  The dough is very sticky; I ended up sticking my hands in ice water, drying them quickly and then rolling about 5 cookies at a time.  Make sure you dry them, otherwise the outside is too damp and the sugar ended up looking like icing. Otherwise the dough stuck to my hands a lot. I did one sheet at a time, on the top shelf and used the convection setting on my oven.  Very good, like eating cooked fudge.

text:
These turned out great the 1st time.  After chilling the dough, you may want to flatten the ball just a little bit before baking so it's a flatter crinkle.  Be careful not to overbake them as they will turn out rough and dry.  Underbaked is better than overbaked because they will still cook when taken out of the oven.

None
text:
Oh my god these were so delicious without any changes! I love how these cookies utilize the 2:1 ratio of sugar to cocoa powder. It is my favourite ratio when using cocoa powder for baking, you get lots of rich chocolate flavour without your dessert getting too sweet. I made 1/4 the full recipe and ended up with 12 cookies. Chilled the dough in the freezer for about 15mins. I baked my cookies on a sheet of parchment paper, set my oven rack to second rack below the top heating element. Cookies crackled perfectly and were done baking in 10mins. Beautiful and yummy!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really great cookie!  Dough is a bit frustrating, as it's very sticky.  Mine sat in the fridge for 2 days covered, until I had time to bake, and all I can say is roll them quickly and keep what you haven't used yet in the fridge.  Love the crackle top.  I will also say that you really need to line the cookie sheets, either with silicon liners or parchment.  I tried both, and the silicon stuck a tiny bit and the parchment released beautifully, as it should.  Next time will only use parchment.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
Sweet!  I mean that figuratively and literally.  :)  We all enjoyed these immensely.  I ate a few more than I was supposed to.  Thanks, Ingrid!  I followed the directions almost exactly--the only change I made was to speed the process by using someone's idea of freezing for forty-five minutes instead of chilling for three hours.  I'm not that patient when I need a sugar fix.  My cookies spread perfectly, and I got a nice crinkle on the top.  I baked in two batches the way some reviewer or other recommended to keep from losing the crinkle effect.  I don't know if it worked or not, because I didn't try it another way, but my cookies were gorgeous!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were extremely good! Perfect for my chocolate fix, though I did kind of alter that. In addition to the 1 c. cocoa, I melted 1 oz semi-sweet bakers chocolate, 1/4 c. dark chocolate chips, and 1/4 c. semi-sweet chocolate chips. Added that to the cocoa/sugar/oil mixture and then kept going with the rest of the ingredients. I also let the batter sit for a couple of hours in my warm kitchen to help the chocolate blend together. Put the batter in the freezer for 6 hours and let it sit on the counter for 30 minutes before I worked with it. I didn't have ANY problems with the dough being too sticky, and my house was pretty warm at the time. Used a #50 scoop and plopped the dough right into the powdered sugar. You HAVE to grease the sheets, otherwise these are a monster to get off the sheet! Overall, GREAT recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty little cookie!  I usually try to cut the fat and sugar, so I made the following modifications.  I used 1C sugar and 1C Splenda, 1/4C oil and 1/4C unsweetened applesauce, and I used 1C Better n'Eggs instead of actual eggs.  I didn't have confectioner's sugar, so I rolled them in granulated sugar, and I greased the cookie sheet instead of using parchment.  At the suggestion of another reviewer, I replaced half of the vanilla with peppermint extract, which was great.  I highly recommend keeping a small bowl of water by the mixing bowl so you can dip your fingers in the water when taking the chilled mix out of the bowl to put in the sugar so it doesn't stick to your hands.  I also put the batter in the freezer for 45 minutes instead of the fridge so I would have my cookies sooner! :-)

text:
Amazing and very simple! For my dad's birthday, I wanted to make him these but his baking supplies were very limited. I had to beat everything with a fork and really doubted that they'd turn out. I was completely wrong, they turned out very nicely, and hardly took any effort at all. I read the reviews first, and put them in the freezer for 45 minutes instead of 4 hours in the fridge, dropping them in the icing sugar before rolling into balls. Thank you so much for this recipe and I'll definitely be making them again. Easier AND better tasting than chocolate chip cookies, that says a lot :)

text:
I'm not understanding all the 5-star ratings.  These tasted "OK", but the batter, even after setting up in the freezer for 1.5 hours, was still extremely soft and difficult to work with.  I had to use one spoon to scoop out the batter and another to scrape the batter off the spoon into the powdered sugar (I used rounded tablespoon. Have no idea what a "#50 scoop" is.)  Only after each blob had some sugar on it could I roll it into a ball without it sticking all over my hands, then I recoated in the sugar before placing on the pan. This process took so long that by the time it went into the oven, the balls had begun to flatten out on their own.  Seriously, these were a lot of work for cookies that taste a whole lot like I took a brownie mix and turned it into an extremely soft cookie dough!

text:
this recipe is great! and my family and boyfriend love them!! and i also found out that it was unnecessary to grease the pans. using ungreased aluminum foil to line the pan or just simply using a nonstick pan is best. greasing the pan (like with butter) just mixes with the powdered sugar and thus caramelizes the sugar.

userID:

Display Name:
TUNISIANSWIFE
isPro:

431
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/933710.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
these get 5 stars for presentation and the fudgy type brownie consistency of the cookie.  I had to re-read the recipe after I got it mixed together for fear I had added too much of a liquid but I hadn't mismeasured anything.  The cookie batter is the consistency and appearance of brownie batter.  It is very soft.  I refrigerated the dough for a couple of hours and using my pampered chef small size cookie scoop, scooped directly into SIFTED confectioner's sugar.  this made it easy to handle and I could then roll into nice balls without any messy fingers.  This made a nice size batch using the smaller cookie scoop.  I did add a tsp of espresso powder to enhance the chocolate.  I think next time I will try adding some melted unsweetened chocolate squares for a deeper chocolate flavor.  these aren't something that can be whipped up and baked in no time; they do take time to refrigerate and roll.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made 1 1/2 times the recipe, added 1/2 cup cocoa (since some people said it wasn't as rich as they expected, and it was too sticky) and 1/4 cup sugar and another Tablespoon good quality vanilla sugar.  I put the dough in the freezer for 1 1/2 hours.  It worked out fine, as, as soon as you start rolling the cookies into balls and gently covering with powdered sugar, some of the sugar stays on your hands and prevents the next cookie from sticking.  I used slightly heaping dessertspoons of the dough.  They turned out great!  (About 135 cookies -- not sure, cuz we were tasting!)

text:
My favorite chocolate cookie recipe ever!  It's amazing how rich and fudgy and chocolately it tastes - almost like a brownie.  It's so moist, yet not at all greasy (and uses so little oil!)  Also, if you take them out of the oven a bit early, they'll be like mini chocolate lava cakes - nice and softish-crunchy on the outside, but gooey and wonderful on the inside :).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love these cookies!! I followed the recipe exactly (except for 1/2 cup more cocoa powder). My dough was not batter like, it was nice and thick. I did not refrigerate the dough prior to baking the first dozen and did not find it hard to handle. I used a cookie scoop and dropped them directly into a plastic bag of confectioners' sugar, rolled them in my hands to make round and placed them on a parchment paper lined cookies sheet. I had no problems with sticking and the cookies crinkled perfectly and had a beautiful shape, no problems with spreading. The remaining dough is in the freezer and I wil see if they bake any differently. I think I'll bake one batch without rolling them in confectioners' sugar and use them to make ice cream sandwiches. YUMMY just thinking about it!!

text:
Really good cookie. Followed directions exactly, and they were perfect.  Used parchment paper and had no trouble with sticking to the pan or spreading.  You might have to re-refrigerate in between batches if it gets a little sticky, but it was actually easier dough to work with than I expected.  Made 45 cookies.  Also, like other reviewers, I just froze the dough for about an hour and it was fine.  My only problem was I had no idea how to tell if they were done, but it ended up working out in the end.

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You definitely have to plop the "dough" (basically a brownie mixture) into the powdered sugar and roll it around to fully coat it. This makes the balls easy to handle and creates the "crinkles." Otherwise it will be sticky and very had to handle. Also followed other raters' advice to put the dough into the freezer about 45 minutes prior to baking. Very helpful. 

These we delicious! I might add a bit more sugar to the dough next time. Tried adding dark chocolate chips and that was great, too!

text:
Great cookie.  I couldn't help but use melted butter instead of veg oil, and they tasted great.  I also greased my baking sheet, and if i hadn't, they would have been stuck to the sheet. I only refrigerated these for about 2 hours, and used a cookie scoop to measure and dropped them right in the powdered sugar.  Once they were in the sugar, they were no problem to roll.  These are a little tricky to tell if they're done, and i ended up cooking them for the full 12 min.  They remind me of the devil food cookies you can buy at a store.  Very pretty and a nice new addition.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6302807.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are pretty good, but the directions should say something about how thin the dough is before chilling.  It seemed way too thin, more like brownie batter than cookie dough, so we thought maybe our eggs were too big or perhaps we didn't measure the vegetable oil correctly and, consequently, we added an extra half-cup of flour before chilling.  Because of this, the cookies aren't quite as fudgy as they probably should be.  If we had been given the information that the "dough" is more like a "batter", we'd have left well enough alone.  The presentation is beautiful, however, and the cookies DO taste good!  Five stars for presentation and taste, three stars for unclear directions, overall - four stars.  Thank you for sharing!

delicious! crispy outside, brownie like inside. bake@second rack from top in the oven in order to 'crinkle', and flatten them slightly because they dont spread much. freezing them for 1.5 hrs is a good way to speed things up if you are pressed for time. i've made these for the past two years every christmas and they are beautiful and easy :) thanks!!

text:
These cookies came out PERFECT!  Just the way I wanted them!!!  I tried another recipe before these, but they flattened out and were dry and hard...very disappointing.  I added a spicy twist to these.  I scaled the recipe down to 18 cookies and used Hershey's Special Dark cocoa and added  1/4 tsp of cracked peppercorn from my Peppercorn Medley and 1/2 tsp of cardamom.  Gave it a very exotic chai tea type flavor.  This recipe is a keeper!

userID:
3748360
Display Name:
SpinningJenny

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not a huge fan of cookies or chocolate, but I made these to take to work for my birthday. My coworkers and my fiance loved them (though the people wearing black pants had to be especially careful ^_^).   I did NOT get a yield of 6 dozen, but I have a tendency to scoop cookies kinda big so I will chalk that up to operator error.  The intenseness of the chocolate was perfect. I added a sprinkle of cinnamon on top of some of the cookies, which was delicious, and would like to try them with a dash of peppermint extract.   I split the dough into 2 bowls, spread thin, and put in the freezer for 45 minutes. Between batches I put the dough back in the freezer so that it wouldn't spread out/warm up. We had a dinner reservation while I was making cookies so I put the last half of the 2nd bowl in the fridge while we were gone, and it was still fairly easy to work with once we got back (except at the very end when I let it get too warm. Watch out--the consistency is like frosting if it's warm and is impossible to work with).   The cookies crinkled perfectly (cooked on 2nd to top rack) and stayed nice and soft inside for days when kept in an airtight container. Some of my coworkers were surprised by the soft texture, expecting them to be really hard like gingersnaps, but were pleasantly surprised by the cookie/brownie hybrid texture.  Great recipe--this will be my go-to cookie recipe from now on, I think. ^_^

text:
Great recipe.  I didn't use confectioner's sugar and the tops still crinkled.  Put the dough in the fridge if you want easy rolling, or you can put them out all spiky.  I had to swap 1/2 the sugar for brown sugar because of what I had on hand, but I think all white is best to get the cookies crisp enough.  Keep them small if you want them crisp - 3/4" balls.  They don't spread much when baking.  I think they tasted better the crisper they were.  I served them to guests who thought they were delicious.

This cookies are simply awesome! My mum's friends couldn't stop praising them! On a side note: Be sure to refrigerate the dough for 45 min. Then use a spoon to scoop the dough into a bowl of confectioners' sugar. Once it's in the sugar, it's easier to roll them into balls.

country:
None
text:
Choco-licious! And here's a trick for avoiding most of the mess. Instead of rolling the sticky dough into an even stickier ball and coating the ball in powdered sugar, try this. Drop a 1-inch spoonful of chilled dough into the powdered sugar and rotate the bowl round and round. The dough will roll itself into a sugar-coated ball, ready for you to pick up and place on the prepared cookie sheet! Alternatively, drop the dough into the powdered sugar and then roll the ball by hand. The sugar keeps the dough from sticking to your palms. These cookies literally fly off the plate...oh, so good!

text:
My husband didn't like it. Too gooey he said. Anyway, after making this awhile ago, I learned that indeed, (1) I should GREASE my pan...(I didn't and the crinkles stuck to the pan like glue!), (2) I should put approximately 1.5-2 inches space between the choco balls coz they will expand during baking, (3) preparation can get a little messy so put a newspaper underneath for easier cleanup. I liked this recipe a lot.

text:
Made this recipe on a snow day with my six year old. Did a recipe search for a recipe without butter since we didn't have any and this is one recipe that popped up. These cookies are sooo good! We were pleasantly surprised, very pretty, and moist in the middle. I did not chill for 4 hours, we couldnt wait that long, and only chilled the dough for a 1/2 hour and they were pretty pretty easy to work with. I did not use parchment paper either, just sprayed a little PAM on the cookie sheet and they came right off, no problem.

None
text:
TIP: This dough, as with all crinkle cookie dough, is very sticky. That's why they are so moist! Use wax paper to pick up teaspoon size clumps (or spray two spoons with cooking spray), and drop right in the powdered sugar. When you have a few in the bowl, use a spoon (or your hands) to cover them with the powdered sugar in the bowl. Then pick them up individually and roll into balls. Works great!!!!!!!!! No sticky hands.
I must admit I like the crinkles made with unsweetened chocolate bars instead powdered cocoa.

userID:
124730
Display Name:
mom26
isPro:

17

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent.  Easy.  My kids love to make these.  I used to make these as a kid and would skip the chilling step--Don't!--the dough is impossible to handle if it isn't cold.  (You can can cheat and put it in the freezer for two hours to speed things up.)  I made this recipe as-is about 6 times and decided the cookie texture is a bit granular.  I now measure the white sugar into the blender and pulverize it first so it's finer.  It makes the end product smoother and fudgier.  (Confectioner's sugar would probably work, too, in the main recipe, but I don't know how much you'd put in.)

I also like to substitute mint extract for the vanilla and roll them in granulated sugar to change things up a bit.  I've also pushed mini candy kisses into the hot baked cookie, like a peanut blossom.

text:
These came out great, and all of the kids in my sons class loved them. I made 72, and none of them made it home from school.

I started to make these, and then I realized I didnt have enough cocoa powder. The recipe calls for sugar and cocoa in a 2:1 ratio. It occurred to me that hot chocolate mix is roughly the same ratio, and I happened to have a large container of it, so I replaced the sugar and cocoa with equal amounts of Ghirardelli Hot Chocolate Mix.

text:
I love these cookies. My daughter has a similar recipe, but this one is just as good and so much easier. They bake up soft and almost like brownies with that wonderful crackle affect. I did what another reviewer suggested. I rolled half of the cookies in powdered sugar and half in granulated sugar before baking. When they came out of the oven, I let the cookies rolled in granulated sugar cool for about a minute, then set a candy kiss firmly on top of each cookie. Both versions were delicious and you would never guess that the cookie base were the same recipe. Great idea! Two cookies with one recipe.

text:
I made the recipe as printed with one small but important exception. When rolling the cookies, drop them in granulated sugar first, then into the confectioner's sugar. It keeps the confectioner's sugar from disappearing into the cookie and the granulated sugar is not noticeable. It leaves the cookies beautifully white and crackled.

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this for a ladies night that included one dairy-free, gluten-free individual.  I wanted them to be chocolate death, thin mint flavored so I substituted 3/4 cup 100 % Cacao (Hershey's special dark) and 1/4 regular, added 1/3 cup dark chocolate chips, two tsp of peppermint extract in place of the vanilla, and used gluten-free all purpose flour that had xanthan gum. I put dark hershey's kisses on some of them right after taking them out of the oven. Decadent and delicious. Tips: Split the dough in two since it warms quickly, freezing makes handling easier than refrigerating, and if you have a partner, one of you can gather the balls, drop it into the sugar and the other can roll in sugar and plop it on the cookie sheets. That's fast and easy with less warming of the dough. Note, there's a small amount of dairy in the chocolate chips and kisses so it's more minuscule dairy than dairy-free this way.

text:
These cookies were just awesome. I was looking for a budget-friendly way to relieve a major sweet tooth, and these cookies killed it. Simple, sweet, long lasting softness (very similar to a brownie), and so aesthetically pleasing. The only changes I made were to half the recipe and add a 1/4 tsp of baking soda to combat the acidity of the cheap baking cocoa I was using. I also allowed the dough to chill for five hours and also, once each cookie-ball was formed, dusted, and on the baking sheet, put the sheet of cookies into the freezer for an extra quick chill while the oven pre-heated. Next time I'll probably skip the powdered sugar dusting because while it is what gives a crinkle it's distinct appearance, it does result in a pretty good mess that just doesn't suit the private snacking for which these cookies were intended.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/916428.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here's a trick for making these cookies: DO NOT roll the dough into balls first! Instead, pour the confectioners' sugar into a pie pan, and then drop teaspoon-sized pieces of dough into the sugar. (You can scoop and drop several pieces of dough at a time into the sugar.) Pick up each piece of dough and roll it around in the confectioners' sugar as you gently shape it into a ball. Your fingers will be "floured" with the confectioners' sugar, which keeps the dough from clinging and makes it MUCH easier than trying to form balls first with the sticky dough! Also recommend using a dark cocoa to intensify the chocolate flavor.

text:
This was a great cookie recipe for any time of year.  Made recipe as written except I used 1/2 cup of plain applesauce instead of vegetable oil as I do with most of my recipes. I put dough in refigerator overnight. First, I made only 9 cookies to test the baking time and to see the result. I put the batter back in the refrigerator while the first batch was cooking.  The first batch spread more than I thought they should. Even before I put them in the oven they were already spreading. I watched the video to see if my dough was consistent with the person in the video.  Mine was softer. I tried putting the cookie sheets, ice cream scoop, smaller dish of batter that I was working with, along with the larger bowl of dough in the refrigerator. They still spread more than they should have. Mine were flatter than the picture but still had crinkles. I dropped them directly in the powdered sugar. I tried not to handle them.  I put the pan on the second shelf of oven while baking. They were very delicious. Maybe it was the applesauce but it never effected other cookies before. Maybe I should try putting them in the freezer instead of the refrigerator. I will try the recipe again. There are so many reviews it must be me. The batch made 47 cookies and I baked them for 10 minutes.

city:

region:

country:

text:
This is one of the best cookies I've ever made (and I've made a lot!). I agree with other reviewers...the flavor and texture is very much like a brownie. I added mini semi-sweet chocolate chips and can't imagine these without them. The chips added the perfect little bit of intense chocolate flavor that complimented the rest of the cookie (I think they would be too plain without the chips).  I used Hershey's Special Dark cocoa powder and added an extra 1/2 tspn of vanilla. 

To get 70 cookies, you have to use a very small scoop (I used the larger end of my double melon baller and got about 70). I think that was a great size for this cookie. They were small but didn't look like mini cookies. 

To deal with the super sticky dough, I pushed the dough out of the melon baller with my finger directly into a bowl of powdered sugar and then coated all of the sides before picking it up and rolling it into a ball in my hand. This worked well but I still had sticky fingers but they're worth it. I can't wait to make them again!

userID:
4011088
Display Name:
jax
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe on its own is good, and if u make it without any changes to the recipe you wont go wrong.  My only issue is that after a few days the cookies aren't as soft as when they were first baked.  You have to let it chill for at least 4 hours or else you wont develop the flavor and the chocolate wont intensify.  

Second time around i made it,  I altered the recipe in my quest to make sure the cookie stayed soft.  I altered it based on another recipe i found.  I changed the oil to butter and melted it,  changed the 2 cups of sugar to 3/4 cup of white sugar and 3/4 cup of brown sugar and add a teaspoon of instant coffee. Best decision i've ever made.  I am so addicted to the cookies after i made the changes and even my boyfriend finished about 20 cookies in 2 days and after 4 days they were still just as soft as when they were first baked and did not dry out. Also made sure I stored it in a ziploc bag.  

There are so many alterations u can do with this cookie recipe and its great for experimentation.  I did also make it with reese's peanut butter chips and was a great peanut butter and chocolate cookie. Next i am going to experiment with rolling it in cinnamon sugar. Try the recipe out,  its good.  Plus it doesn't require alot of dishes,  which is always a plus in my book.

text:
great recipe overall. couple things- I used a stand mixer with paddle attachment, with the exception of mixing dry ingredients, which I used a whisk for. I added 2 ounces of chopped 85% baking chocolate to the wet mixture before adding eggs. I used olive oil for veg oil and added a little bit more vanilla to balance out the extra chocolate. I made bigger cookies and baked for 16 minutes. only refrigerated for about 2.5 hours in a stainless steel bowl. came out perfect. I did three dozen in three batches. be generous with the confectioners sugar and use a fairly high rack in your oven. can't stop eating these cookies!

Woooohooo!! What an amazing recipe. Came out perfect! So chocolatey and so delicious. The only couple changes I made - 1) used butter as I like to bake with butter only - no issues. My batter was probably thicker than would have been with oil but caused no issues and the cookies are still fudgey and delicious. 2) Next time I will reduce the sugar in the dough. I may have coated my cookies too well to get a nice crinkle but it caused them to be a little too sweet for my taste. Such a satisfying baking experience! :)

Halving the recipe yielded 24 cookies with a little extra dough (for taste testing, of course!). Oh my, these are absolutely delicious! I could not stop eating them. They had a soft, fudgey texture, not overly chewy or anything like that.  I added 1/2 cup of chocolate chips (halved the recipe) for an extra chocolatey boost. It's a lot easier to scoop some dough up, drop it into the sugar, and then roll it, otherwise your hands will be a huge mess. Such a fantastic recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These came out great! I refrigerated the batter for 4 hours as indicated in the recipe. It was still sticky but I continued with it anyway. The stickiness was actually good for getting a good coating of powdered sugar, if you don't mind dealing with the mess. They still held a nice ball shape on the cookie sheet. I lined the sheet with parchment paper and they had no trouble sticking. I baked for 11 minutes and let them cool on the sheet. They seemed fragile coming out of the oven, but firmed up enough to put on a tray and transport. I added a Tablespoon of instant espresso to the batter that gave a nice mocha flavor. They had a nice soft brownie-like texture inside. My husband could not stop eating them!

This is an outstanding cookie.  The texture and flavor is perfect. They are somewhat like a brownie in cookie form. I can't imagine making these without using a small melon baller, though.  These cookies make a nice presentation. I used a whole cup of confectioners sugar for coating and I baked them for 11 minutes and left them on the cookie sheet for an additional minute as per instructions.  They store well in an airtight container with parchment between layers and taste even better the following day.

These are great...for the novice (like me), a 50 whatever spoon is NOT a tablespoon size...I used a tablespoon and got half the cookies...go smaller...these are nice and rich, almost brownie like.  also, the recipe doesn't say electric mixer...saw that in the video after I made the batter...that would have been handy up front.  my forearms are talking to me after mixing it by hand.   Great recipe and will do again...smaller...and with an electric mixer.  Enjoy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe for the first time tonight.  I have never eaten or seen this cookie before but found it while perusing the site for some new chocolate desserts.  I need to make a variety of chocolate desserts  for a chocolate and champagne event I do at my home in December and this looked very snowy and good for the season. It also looked pretty easy and I had all the ingredients on hand so I decided to give them a try. I refrigerated the dough for 4-5 hours. 

I can't believe I have baked for so many years and never come across these cookies.  They were so easy and came out so perfectly. I baked them for 15 minutes and that was just right for my oven. I ended up with 4 dozen instead of 6 so that is probably why mine took a little longer. I put parchment on the cookie sheets and could lift off easily with my hand. No sticking at all. 

I made the first two batches exactly according to the recipe and then added a handful of chocolate chips and macadamia nuts to the last two.  Both were very good but really do taste like a cake-like brownie. 

I have had a lot of trouble lately with my cookies going flat so I was delighted that they kept their mounded shaped.  I rolled the balls in quite a bit of powdered sugar and it stayed on beautifully  making the perfect affect. They looked just like in the pictures.

text:
Ran out of white sugar so had to use mostly brown sugar in the recipe.  I also substituted 2-3 Tb of black cocoa for part of the cocoa powder to make it extra chocolaty. Dough was like brownie batter so I put in freezer for a few hours and then it was fine to scoop & roll in powdered sugar.  They turned out great, everyone loved them. Best part is that the dough is perfect for freezer because it stays soft so there's no need to thaw it out - just scoop & roll.

Awesome cookies!  I used Hershey's Cocoa and added about 1 cup of Ghiardelli mini chocolate chips to the batter.  Rich chocolate flavor. Crispy outer layer with brownie like inner cookie.  Very pretty to serve and give as a gift. Please do refrigerate the dough for a few hours before forming the balls and rolling in confectioner's sugar.  It makes for much easier handling. I made my cookies slightly larger and got 45 from the batch.  I baked for 11 minutes on second oven rack from the top.  Perfect!

text:
I love chocolate crinkles, and this was my first attempt at making them. I got a bit worried when, after 12 minutes of baking, the cookies were still very soft, but as they cooled they solidified and were just great! The outside is a bit crunchy while inside it's fudgy and chewy. I had to put the plate away to stop myself from eating too much. 

I greased my pan instead of using parchment paper, and it turned out fine. I also froze the batter for about an hour, as I live in a hot and humid country and I was scared of having runny batter. Next time I'll try the advice of another reviewer and put some dark chocolate.

Made these and followed the tweaks for the second upper rack in the oven.  I left the dough in the fridge over night, no rush to bake them.  The dough was perfect for rolling in the powdered sugar, no problems at all.  Used parchment paper, always use it.  I have 3 pans on the go at once, take one out and put one in.  You can use the same piece of parchment for the for all the baking time, they did not stick at all.  I used the Ghiradelli cocoa and added dark chocolate mini chunks gave it amazing chocolate flavour.  They were a huge hit and they freeze well.  Making them again this week.  two thumbs up!!!!!

text:
These are FANTASTIC!   I have always loved crinkle cookies, just had never made them myself.  I was looking for a little chocolate fix earlier this week, and didn't have too many things in the pantry to work with, but I had almost enough cocoa powder to make 1/4 of this recipe.  They turned out absolutely amazing.  I took the advice of another reviewer and stuck the batter in the freezer for about 25 minutes (didn't take long with a small batch), but they were not sticky at all when I rolled them and threw them in the powdered sugar.  Aside from not having any whole eggs, so I had to sub egg whites, I followed the recipe exactly, they crinkled perfectly in the oven, and they are now my new favorite cookies to make!  I love so much that they don't contain any butter and very little oil.  Thanks for the awesome recipe!

IF YOU DON'T CHILL THE BATTER, THEY WON'T WORK!  :)


(if you're matching my photo with the review, I show both, the failed and the good cookies in my photo.  One difference on the 'good' cookies was that I used Hershey Special Dark coco on the good ones whick made them extra pretty).


Sad but true.  I made two batches of these in two days.  The first batch I was impatient and didn't chill the batter well.  They were awful.  They came out flat and had the miserable yellowish looking powdered sugar like others have complained about.  I threw them out and immediately made another batch.  Put it in the fridge overnight and rolled and cooked them the following day.  PERFECT and just beautiful as they should be!!  Don't take short cuts here because you will be disappointed!  By the way, they are so delicious and taste like little Brownies!

text:
I really liked these.  They are sort of like a donut cookie. I added a tbsp of coffee (you don't taste the coffee, it just brings out the chocolate flavor), and just a tad more cocoa powder and flour to compensate the extra liquid.  I also used half regular sugar and half brown sugar (not sure if it makes a huge difference - it's what I had on hand - but I've heard brown sugar could give a richer flavor to the chocolate as well). Greased my pans, froze the cookie dough for 40 minutes, and dropped spoonfuls directly into the powdered sugar and then used my hands to roll them around, and there was no mess or sticky dough on my hands. Everyone enjoyed them.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing cookies!. Made these numerous times and this has always been a crowd-pleaser. I suggest adding a tsp of strong coffee or instant espresso powder to bring out the chocolate flavor. I also like to add 1/2 of almond extract sometimes and reduce the vanilla. I know it sounds weird but people really seem to love that combination! Also after many trials and errors, I have found that the secret to getting these to crinkle beautifully lies in how  you press them down. You really need to refrigerate for at least an hour. I use a larger melon baller to get perfect bite-size cookies. Coat them a thick layer of powder sugar and shake the excess off gently. then only press them down slightly with your thumb, not too much. This way they spread more while baking and thus you get a nicer crinkle.

text:
This cookie is enough to satisfy any chocolate craving.  Followed the recipe as is but didn't level the cocoa in the measuring cup, so maybe added about 1/8 of a cup more than recipe calls for.  Froze dough for about an hour and put it back in the freezer after filling up a cookie sheet.  Used a scoop to scoop the dough into the confectioners surge which was a time saver and kept my hands pretty clean.  Had to bake the cookies for 15 minutes.  The first batch I put in for 12 and they were raw in the middle, had to toss them.  The ones baked for 15 minutes were a keeper.  Can't wait to make this recipe again.

HELP! I did something wrong. After letting it chill (covered, in the fridge) for probably 16 hours or so, the batter was just that: batter. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe exactly except I put the dough in the freezer for 45 minutes.  I just took a spoonful of dough, dropped it into a bowl of powdered sugar, rolled it in the bowl until covered, and then in my hands.  I had no issues with sticking doing it this way.  Also, to grease the cookie sheets I sprayed Pam down the center of the sheet and then used my fingers to spread it around the entire cookie sheet.  This left the perfect amount.  My cookies did not go flat like others mentioned and turned out beautifully.  I had no problems with the cookie sticking to the cookie sheet either.  I don't get the "not chocolately enough" comments as  I think they are fabulous!  Just a matter of personal preference I guess.

text:
I followed all of the directions but cut the recipe in half. I Pammed the cookie sheets quite thoroughly and most of the cookies came off with just a little twist, not even needing the spatula. Most of them look great, although the oil that was on my hands absorbed and dulled the sugar in some places. I had to put the bowl back in the freezer between batches because the dough was starting to stick to my hands quite a bit. They all crinkled just right and they taste quite a bit like brownies, which is fine by me! My parents love them. They're so easy to make, and I'll definitely be making them again.

text:
These aren't too sweet, have a nice flavor and light texture, but the confectioner's sugar melted into the cookies. In the spots where it remained, it took on a yellowish cast. I read on Martha Stewart's version of this recipe to roll the dough in granulated sugar before the powdered sugar, to make it adhere better. I don't know if it would work, but I would probably try that next time, if I make these again--though I will reduce the sugar a bit if I do coat with granulated sugar. Honestly, I probably won't bother to roll these cookies in anything next time.

text:
Made according to recipe except made 21 large cookies. Baked 16 min. and let cool on cookie pans for about 5 min. These cookies are a 'wow' to look at and the texture and moisture are perfect. I counted down one star because they are more like cocoa crinkles than chocolate crinkles. I'm missing the rich chocolate taste, but I will be making these again with some modifications to improve the chocolate flavor.edit: tried enhancing chocolate flavor using 1 cup chocolate chips-don't do it! changed texture and appearance-third time I melt 4 oz. unsweetened chocolate with the oil and followed rest of directions and they were chocolate heaven!

Great!  Followed the directions and they came out perfect - like little brownies!  I did make mine a little bigger.  I used my cookie scoop (which is about 1 1/2 Tbsp.) and got 3 dozen cookies. text:
These were tasty, pretty and easy to make.  I put the dough in the freezer for about 45 min. and had no trouble rolling into balls.  To get the cookies coated in sugar, I used 2 small bowls and a few cookies in the bowl that had the sugar then dumped the whole thing in a second bowl and went back and forth a few times.  Piece of cake. I would have liked the cookies to have more chocolate flavor.  Maybe next time I will add chocolate liqueur or even more cocoa powder. The texture was wonderfully chewy on the inside, even after a few days. Thanks for the great recipe!

Cookie Monster

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never made this cookie before but I have eaten many of them. So today I got brave and with the help of all of the reviews here I made my first Chocolate crinkle cookies. This recipe was so easy. The two things I took out of the reviews that helped were the time the dough was chilled and how to bake them. This was key to making a perfectly chewy cookie. I split my dough in fourths and let it chilled for 4 hours and it was easier to roll into balls as long as I removed only a fourth of the dough at a time. The other was baking the cookies on the 2nd to the top rack. Ten minutes of baking was perfect in my oven. I will make these again....

city:

country:
None
text:
SO YUM!! SO BRILLIANT!! SO CHRISTMASY n snowy and LOVELY!! I added 1 tsp of cinnamon to the dry ingredients to give it more of a flavor of the season. Apart from that I did exactly as the recipe stated except...I refrigerated the dough for about 2days before baking (coz I couldn't bake sooner) and I poped the dough back in the fridge after filling on baking sheet. Like anouther reviewer suggested, I took 1 inch balls and dropped them into icing sugar. rolled them and coated them well with sugar. instead of making them into balls and then dropping them into sugar, since they are sticky just drop them into the sugar let them coat and then form them into balls. Perfect. You simply can't go wrong! Just coat really well...they'l crack beautifully. Also they were done in about 11 minutes, after which I pulled them out and left them on the tray for about 2-3 mins and then transferred them onto wired racks. Thanks Ingrid! :)

userID:
1206033
Display Name:
KMCONWAY
isPro:

9

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are fabulous- moist, chewy, and so chocolaty. My family loves them! (We call them "Chocolate Kringles" at Christmas time!) The dough is very soft and is like cake batter- I freeze the dough for 45 minutes like another reader suggested and that really makes it easier to handle. When you're ready to roll them, drop the dough directly from your scoop or spoon into the confectioner's sugar, roll it around a little, and then roll into a ball with your hands. (I do this right over the sink, makes clean up easier!) Then, roll in the confectioner's sugar again to make sure you have enough sugar on them so they crinkle. Keep the dough in the fridge between batches, too, so it doesn't get too soft. Thanks for a great recipe, Ingrid- it's a keeper!!

These weren't bad, but they could be better. I put them in the freezer for 45 minutes instead of in the fridge and they were super easy to work with-but they got more sticky and fudge-ier the longer they were out, so work fast! Also, I think next time I make them I'll add chocolate chips or something. Oh, and I won't grease the cookie sheets-it ended up being a mess and seemed unnecessary. Nice and chewy on the inside and slightly crunchy on the outside. It will be fun to mix these with our other holiday cookies.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! They taste like little brownies! The only change I made to the recipe was to use 3/4 of the called-for sugar instead of the full amount. They were a cinch to make, and I find it very confusing how so many people are having a runny batter with these cookies. I mean, there's hardly any liquid in them. The batter was very thick for me even before I refrigerated it overnight. I know I didn't mix it wrong because I made my first batch, then mixed up another half batch because I didn't think one was enough, and both came out the same consistency. (The 1.5 recipe yielded 75 cookies, by the way.) I coated the 1-inch cookie balls well with the powdered sugar and baked them on the second to top rack for 10 minutes. They came out perfect! So yummy!! Will definitely make again.

text:
I'm not a chocolate fan but I heard nothing but "mmmm.. omg... sooo good.. mmmm.. omg.. sooo good" from my husband and kids.  I used half the recipe and it's made about 30 or so cookies.  I used parchment paper the first batch with no sticky issues and have the second batch with spray canola oil for the second batch *don't know the results yet*.  The best idea is the 45 min in the freezer, does make it much easier to handle.  I put the icing sugar in a ziploc bag; used a large soup spoon to dig it out of the bowl; then scraped it off the spoon with the sides of the bag.  NO MESS!  Once it is in the sugar it is much easier to handle and mold. FABULOUS recipe!  Baked on the second from the top shelf for the 10-12 minutes and it looks JUST like the photo! THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR OUR NEW FAV COOKIE!

text:
I'm very surprised so many people gave these cookies a good review, i found them too bitter though the texture was good. i would recommend using a 1/2 cup butter instead of the vegetable oil, 4 oz unsweetened chocolate (melted) in place of the cocoa, and decrease the baking powder to 1 teaspoon - these small changes make a WORLD of difference in these cookies.

I would make these again with a few changes. I liked the flavor p[retty well, but I didn't like that these didn't spread out at all, I just prefer a larger, more spread out cookie. So, I would make a larger dough ball and maybe press it down or reduce the flour? I added a cup of semi-sweet chocolate chips, which I liked, but I want to try milk chocolate instead, I think the semi-sweet was a smidge too bitter.  Also, I didn't need to put down parchment paper, these came up fairly well from a calphalon cookie sheet.

text:
These cookies were soooo good! I made one minor change. Instead of oil, I used applesauce.  They turned out really pretty and tasty.  The dough is sticky even after refrigerating it.  My solution was to drop spoonfuls into the powdered sugar itself, coat the dough and then roll them.  I then coated the balls again with powdered sugar before placing them on the cookie sheet.  It's easier and faster this way.

text:
I've always loved the cake mix version, but being out of cake mix, I decided to try my hand at homemade. I halved the batch and used melted margarine instead of oil. Much better flavor than cake mix chocolate crinkles-more chocolatey, more tender texture. Unfortunately, they were also a little dryer ont he edges, even with the middle remaining rather gooey. That's probably my fault for subbing margarine. Overall, a good cookies that will remain a favorite, even when I'm out of cake mix.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this recipe, though I didn't present them to friends as "cookies" but as "two-bite brownies" because the consistency suggested to me that's how they would be best received. If you put this in your mouth expecting a cookie taste you might be disappointed, but if you are expecting a fudge brownie you will die of joy.  A tip: I happened to have run out of powdered sugar, but I used an old housewives substitution of 1 cup regular sugar run in a blender with 1 tbsp cornstarch to make my own.  Another tip: I chilled the batter/dough overnight, instead of just four hours, before scooping it with a spoon into the powdered sugar. That way, it handled just fine.

None
text:
This recipe is absolutely perfect. Easy, too. It yields deliciously moist and chocolaty cookies that are the perfect cross between a brownie and cookie. I followed the recipe exactly, except I used olive oil instead of plain veg oil. I got 40 cookies using a mini ice cream scoop. I chilled for 4.5hrs, and the dough was very easy to work with by then, though the ice cream scoop helped tremendously. Finally, definitely don't flatten the balls before putting them in the oven - they'll flatten on their own while baking. Thank you! A life-long keeper!!!!!

text:
These taste like very good brownies. Very rich and satisfying, I baked them to give away to friends during valentines and I had some of them tell me they liked it. Personally though, I thought they were a little too sweet for my liking so if I were to bake for myself or for people who don't like overly sweet deserts I will reduce the sugar. The crinkled effect makes the cookie look really professional. I also found that the dough balls after being rolled in the confectioners sugar tends to absorb some of it so you don't want to flake away too much of the sugar or they wont appear properly white.

This recipe literally made my day!  

I was getting ready for a cookie swap and having a bad baking day.  The first cookie recipe I tried were terrible and didn't turn out.  I realized I had no confectioners sugar and we were having a blizzard-so I made some, then I burned my last 4 squares of baking chocolate in the microwave.  All I had was cocoa powder so I Googled "Chocolate Crinkles with cocoa powder" and the first hit was this recipe.  These came out FANTASTIC, moist & chewy!  I am not a big chocolate person normally and I couldn't keep away from these.  They are wonderful and really turned my day around.
THANK YOU SO MUCH!

text:
This is an absolutely fabulous recipe.  I followed the advice of others and put the dough in the freezer for about an hour instead of waiting on the fridge.  Rolling the dough is a sticky job -- I washed my hands after about every half dozen, and that made rolling easier.  I also reused the same two pieces of parchment paper for the whole recipe, and that caused no problems.  

This one's going on my "favorites" list.

text:
I like buttery cookies and these tasted like they were made with, well, oil.  The flavor was flat and I would have given these three stars, but my husband says this is what they're supposed to taste like and he thought they were good, so four stars.  On the plus side, they're very pretty and easy to make (drop the dough from spoons directly into powdered sugar and roll from there.)  Will probably make these again, maybe subbing melted butter for the oil and adding some sort of spice to pick up the flavor.  If you want a pretty, tasty cookie, try the Meatball Cookies from this site.  They're awesome and easy too.

text:
I actually made these vegan for my roommates (as they are vegans) and had to make a few adjustments. (I used 1tbls of white vinegar and 1tsp of baking soda for each egg) and had to add a little extra oil to get it to stick. the batter was never quite as thin as in the video but you can't even taste that these were vegan. I brought them later to my friends house for a dinner party and everyone asked for th recipe not even realizing that I made them with vegan substitutions. 10/10 will make again both vegan and non vegan ways

text:
My son and I made these for Santa - three batches, one from recipe and one for each of our tastes.  They are great 'as is' a tasty brownie cookie.  Like others have commented, use plenty of powdered sugar to get the magnificent crackled look.  For his, we added a tsp of peppermint to make mint chocolate brownies.  For mine, we added a tsp of cayenne pepper and a tsp of Mexican vanilla to make 'hot chocolate' brownies.  We added green and red sprinkles to the powdered sugar so we could tell the three versions apart.

text:
Followed the recipe except for measuring out the dough for the cookies. I just eye-balled it. Mine were a little thicker and rounder than pictured but were absolutely delish! In my electric oven, cooking for 11 minutes was perfect.

Rather than "rolling" the balls in confectioners sugar, I put some confectioners sugar in bowl, dropped the dough balls in, shook them around and dropped them on the cookie sheet.

These will be a holiday staple!

text:
These cookies are SO good! I make them every year for Christmas and they're always a hit. I typically make them as-is and throw some chocolate chips in the dough at the end for an extra punch of chocolate, but this year I used dark cocoa powder in place of the regular powder (it's what I had on hand) and it was absolutely delicious. 

Be sure to thoroughly chill the dough or they'll spread a bit. I always pop the bowl of dough into the freezer for a while.

text:
Very good chewy cookie. I was skeptical at first because the dough was SO gooeey. But I put it in the fridge overnight (2-3 hours should be good though) or as some reviewers suggested in the freezer until it firms up just a bit. I used a melon scooper to scoop them out, I like smaller cookies. Baked for about 9-10 minutes but ovens vary so start with the lower time and check on them every minute or so. Delicious!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great! So easy and very tasty. I substituted with 1 teaspoon peppermint extract since I was making it for a holiday cookie exchange party. I thought it was a little too much peppermint but my sister and nephews loved it. So if you want a hint of peppermint use less but if you want a good peppermint flavor 1 teaspoon is perfect. I made three different cookies and these were the best. To get the crinkle make sure you fully coat with powdered sugar and move the rack to the upper part of the oven ( I used the second slot in mine). Also, dont dip them in powder then put on the tray that is sitting on top of the hot oven, the powder will start to melt into the cookie and you lose the effect. I will definitely make these again.
Review:
Rating:
5

Delicious as instructed. Used a medium cookie scoop which yielded about 40 cookies. However, I am trying to mail these out today and didnt have four hours to refrigerate. These cookies turned out fabulous! So pretty and so tasty! Im here to tell you though, that the dough DOES NOT NEED TO CHILL FOR FOUR HOURS. I didnt have any time for chilling, but I tried them anyway. I stuck the dough in the freezer for 15 minutes because thats all the time I had, and they baked perfectly. I also rolled them in granulated sugar simply because I was out of powdered sugar, and they tasted and looked divine. Everyone raved about them. I will try them in powdered sugar next time. These will be one of my go-to cookies from now on!

text:
The easiest and yummiest recipe!  I've shared it with many friends! 
The best advance from another baker was to cut dough in half (one half at a time is more than enough) and freeze for 45 minutes instead of refrigerating for hours. Then you always have a spare batch ready for company in the freezer, all you have to do is roll, dunk in powdered sugar and bake!

text:
Delicious, fudge-y cookies! I love how they taste exactly like a brownie. These are my new favorite cookie. I used coconut oil as my oil, and they didnt taste coconut-y at all. The saturated fat in coconut oil makes it a better option than vegetable oil. Also, I halved the recipe, but kept the vanilla extract the same measure. At 3 hours the dough was hard, so I had to let it sit out for a half hour. This is the best cookie.

I made these cookies the other night and let me say they were absolutely AMAZING!!! I was a little to eager to wait 4 hours for the dough to chill in the fridge so I covered it and put it in the freezer for 1 hour. It worked out perfectly. As for rolling the dough, it's very sticky so I used a pair of disposable gloves and it made thing super easy. I totally recommend this recipe to anyone trying to get their chocolate fix!!!

Very good recipe!  Ive tried others that came out super crispy which I didnt like.  This recipe came out with a chewy center and a nice slightly crisp exterior.  If your not a fan of heavy confectioner sugar (can be cloyingly sweet) you may want to be super light handed on rolling the balls in the sugar or only dip the top half before placing them on the sheet.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5221600.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The BEST chocolate crinkle ever! It was perfect as the sweetness was just right and iit's chewy that everyone in my family loves it, even the ones that are not fan of eating chocolates, they said they like it! I did 2 sets, i ended up having 100 pcs. I tried to wet my hands to make it round as what the other user says in the reviews but i ended up contributing or adding water to the crinkle itself and when it came out it was burnt easily. So Based on my experience, it would be easier to make it into a ball size using one tablespoon measurement that has a rounded bottom. I used teaspoons to make the edges round, transferring, alternating in between teaspoons. Also do take note that you can make it even more rounder when you're coating it with the icing sugar. I did 9 minutes on a 176C temperature. Thank you for this recipe.

country:
None
text:
I used Ghiradelli cocoa and I also added 1/4 tsp Hersheys special dark cocoa. I chilled the dough for 24 hours and had no issues with rolling them- I made a ball shape and then dipped in powdered sugar before rolling a bit more and then dipping again. I used parchment paper and baking spray- no issues with sticking and I transferred them to a rack 5 minutes after taking them out. They turned out wonderful! Fudgy and delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my favorite Christmas cookie, and one we make every year! We almost always add about a cup of mini chocolate chips, although we change up the flavors. We've done all semisweet, a mix of semisweet and dark, and (my personal favorite) mint chocolate! 

One thing we've done in the past when traveling is make the dough ahead of time, then refrigerate in plastic-wrapped logs. (I imagine they would freeze just fine too.) Then we just roll em out, dip, bake, and voila! Fresh, homemade cookies! 

I saw another review that recommended adding a bit of cinnamon and dipping them in a mix of cinnamon and powdered sugar, which I will definitely be trying this year as I bet it's delicious.

text:
I used a #40 scoop because I didn't have a #50 so I got just over 3 dozen cookies from this recipe. The dough was very sticky and somewhat difficult to scoop, but the effort was worthwhile. The result was a cookie that has a crisp outside and a chewy inside and a flavor reminiscent of a brownie. The chocolate flavor is assertive but not cloying and I think the sweetness is just right. I might add some espresso powder to the next batch for a little bump in flavor. I'm definitely adding this recipe to my holiday cookie collection.

I will be making more TOMORROW!!!!
I think I've eaten about 7 of these today (sorry not sorry)
This recipe is so delicious. 
Make sure you take them out of the oven when they still look a ~little~ gooey on top In the center. 
There is a very fine line between PERFECT chocolate crinkle cookies and BURNT chocolate crinkle cookies.
 also, letting them cook for a few minutes on the cookie sheet fresh out of the oven is V important.
BRB going to grab my eighth cookie!!!
(they taste just like brownie bites!!!!!!!!)

userID:
14204691
Display Name:
Aireen Ong
isPro:
False

0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1410027.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
1st time to make it for a charity event sale and it's already perfect!  The remaining pieces, we ate in a few days (with self control), but we could have easily eat it in just a day because it's so yummy! Looks great and so appetizing too! My husband and daughter liked it a lot. The only reason I won't be making it is to not ruin my diet. Because it's really hard to resist it when it's sitting on the kitchen counter.

By the way, it's perfect when dipping with coffee or milk! 

I reduced the sugar by 1/4 and the sweetness is just perfect. I suggest to put some powdered sugar on the plate after you rolled them (I rolled few balls first before putting in the powdered sugar bowl) since I noticed that they are sticking on the plate. I just put it in the fridge overnight. The dough melts a bit in my hand when I'm on the 5th ball and it became too sticky. So next time, I'll try to put in the freezer for 1 hour so it's cooler. 

Using parchment or baking paper is amazing on this cookie. I read someone said that parchment paper is too valuable in the kitchen. You don't need a lot of parchment paper because you can just use just one for all 3 or more batches in the oven. And you only need to bake one at a time since this should be in 2nd from the highest rack in the oven. 

Too glad I've found this recipe. Can't wait to make more!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6090593.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's soft and chewy and very sweet. I reduced the sugar to half and might tweak the recipe a little bit more to my preference next time. I read and followed the comments and other member's suggestions. I placed it in in the freezer for 45mins to 1 hour, then scooped it directly to the confectioner's sugar and rolled it to medium sized balls (about an inch and a half thick) then baked it. Overall, this is a really good and easy recipe.

text:
I originally made this from the Betty Crocker cookie book when I was about 12. This was my first successful cookie I ever made. This recipe is very similar except that I use Olive Oil instead of vegetable. The only reason was that I didn't have the latter on hand when I first made these. I find that they are more fluffier and brownie like with olive oil than with vegetable. If you use olive oil, not that it just smells weird when in batter form.

I saved this recipe awhile ago and just got around to making them today. After having a cookie similar last weekend in Door County, Wisconsin, I made a few changes. I added a bag of dried cherries and used one teaspoon of almond extract and one vanilla. They turned out very soft and flavorful. The recipe is a great starting point. The next time Im going to add walnuts along with the cherries. During the holidays I may use peppermint extract or even candy canes. But the best thing about this recipe is they are dairy free! Having two kids who have a dairy intolerance, finding recipes that dont use dairy makes this momma very happy.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4179909.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are perfect. I make the dough in the morning and refrigerate it until afternoon. I use a cookie scoop, plop it in a bowl of confectionary sugar, roll it around and then cook for 10 minutes. You absolutely do not need to grease the parchment paper. The cookies slide right off. I pull them at exactly 10 minutes and then leave them on the cookie sheet while I get the next bunch ready to go in the oven. (So between 3 & 5 minutes depending on how many times I get interrupted lol) In between sheets of cookies I throw the dough in the freezer to keep it cold and workable.  Adding some peanut butter chips to the dough is also fantastic. Oh, and the tops of the cookies are suppose to "crack"....that's what makes them look so cool!

Literally so freaking GOOD.  Ok so here's the deal- I slightly up the cocoa to make them more chocolatey....and immediately put the batter in the FREEZER...let it sit 20 mins....and mold into balls and dunk into powder sugar, then flatten. text:
Amazing cookies - and can easily be made vegan by substituting flax egg (1 tbsp ground flax and 2.5 tbsp water for each egg)!! I've made these multiple times (vegan and not) and have added melted chocolate, chocolate chips, or cinnamon on occasion. I always pop the batter in the freezer for about half an hour before scooping, which works perfectly.

country:

text:
I made two batches on the same day, each time following the recipe exactly!  I also used the trick of raising the oven rack  to the second notch.  The first batch was made using dutched process cocoa.  They were soft inside and  puffy and... very crackled.  FABULOUS!  Just like mom used to make.  Plenty of great chocolate flavor.   The  only difference in the second batch was using regular cocoa (much cheaper)which made two differences in the outcome.  The cookies were not as puffy and the chocolate was not nearly as  rich.  I'll make these over and over but only using the dutch cocoa!! And, by the way...LOTS of powdered sugar!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of my favorite cookie recipes, these are no fail! Ive made them a couple of times before and they always turn out decadent! Like other reviewers suggested, before you shape the dough, throw the dough into a freezer or refrigerator to harden up. I also make sure to add a cup of chocolate chips or hand-chopped chocolate chunks, once baked, the chocolate turns gooey and gives the cookie a brownie-lava cake like texture. Ive found that baking them for only ten minutes is perfect and letting them cool is key. If I go over that time, theyll be as hard as rocks.  If youre looking for a Christmas cookie recipe, these are perfect! Around the holidays, I add a teaspoon or two of peppermint extract and it tastes just like a York peppermint patty!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
These were a HUGE hit with my family and friends at Christmas. 
This is a sticky dough so I found it much easier to plop the spoon or scoopful of dough in the powdered sugar and then form into balls while rolling around in the sugar. Also, I kept the dough chilled in between baking batches to help cut down on the stickiness while handling.

text:
I refrigerated dough for about 2 hrs. Then I  rolled the balls and put pan in refrigerator while I rolled 2nd pan. Then rolled all in powdered sugar. Cookies stayed thick. PS: This is a thick batter used bowl mixer with the dough hook.  I watched video after I made them. Rolling one inch balls does not yield 6 doz cookies but a fair amount . They are not overly sweet but very chocolatey. This is a keeper.. Thank you

text:
It is wonderful to find an already dairy free recipe that I didn't have to substitute at all.  These are very light tasting, which I enjoyed but I worried that others might want a stronger flavor. 

Well chilled dough using a cookie scoop and dropping the dough straight into a bag of powdered sugar changed slow tedious ball formation into a quick and easy process.  I also used the second rack from the top technique to make sure they cracked.

text:
These were super annoying to make and only tasted okay for the effort. I followed another reviewer's advice and dropped the dough right into the powdered sugar for covering. That helped a ton. After two pans in the oven, I added about a quarter cup more cocoa to the batter to: 1. add more chocolate flavor and 2. make them a little easier to scoop and cover. The cocoa helped a ton, but they were still just okay when out of the oven. They looked better and more crinkly too with the additional cocoa. I won't make them again, but my seven year old daughter says they are worth the effort.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4937635.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very pretty and easy to make. The reason for 3 stars is that in terms of taste the cookies are not really interesting. They are kind of tasteless and just not "chocolaty" enough. If I make them net time, will add melted bitter chocolate, may-be it will solve the problem.
I changed a few things: 
- reduced sugar to 1.3 cup, next time will reduce more, they are still too sweet.
- replaced the oil with room temperature butter and whipped it with sugar. Worked great, really recommend to ppl like me who hate smelling oil in bakery.
- added 0.5 tea spoon of chilly to enhance the cocoa, it was not enough, next time will add a full spoon.
I let the dough chill well in the fridge before forming the cookies, this made the process easier.
