country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe, used some tips from previous reviews - freeze 45 min. prior to rolling, I may have left them an extra 5 minutes,.  Saves waiting 5 hours and they dont stick to hands. I used both 1tbls and 1/2 tbls. to scoop the batter and roll, I preferred the 1/2 tbls they are smaller than the size recommended in the recipe but the cookies  expand and are a nice bite size.  Experimented baking on the second rack from top as a previous review suggested and the middle rack per recipe. Both resulted in crackles, preferred cookie texture from the middle rack and 12 minutes baking. They look beautiful and will be a Christmas regular.

userID:
22493181
Display Name:
mom3kids
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made as shown except to give it a holiday taste I used 1 teaspoon of peppermint extract in place of 1 teaspoon of the vanilla. They were done in 10 minutes. They rose and crackled nicely. I got 70 out of the 72 they say it will make. I did not have to freeze mine as others suggested. Yes it's a little sticky but not that much. Some suggestions: [1] Use more powdered sugar than shown and make sure the cookie is heavily covered. Once you move them from the cooking sheet to your cooling rack, you can always tap the rack to knock more off. [2] Make sure you are using baking powder and not baking soda. If your cooking isn't cracking that could be the problem. [3] Keep unused portion in the refrigerator until ready to make your next batch to cook. [4] Coat your hands with powdered sugar while rolling into a ball. It's not going to hurt and besides, you're going to put more powdered sugar on them anyways. [5] Be sure to use the parchment paper. I used one sheet per cooking sheet and used that same sheet each time I baked.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was super easy and fun to make. I used a small ice cream scoop and got about 2 dozen cookies. I also cooked them for 13 minutes because the cookie was larger. 
To help reduce mess, I poured powdered sugar into a large Tupperware dish and dropped ice cream scoops of dough directly into the sugar, sprinkled sugar on top so the dough wouldn't stick to me and then rolled dough into balls. Afterwards, I rolled all the balls in more powdered sugar before placing on greased pans. Wonderful crinkling from this approach and a ton of powdered sugar. 
I'd definitely make this again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great and delicious! I had to make some changes though. I have baked this three times and I finally got the perfect crinkle appearance that I want. First time, the dough was so sticky and will start to melt in my hands. I baked them in a convection oven and they spread too much. Second time, I put the dough in the freezer and it was so much easier to work with but when I baked them, they still looked like the first one that I baked. Just earlier I made this again with all hopes that this will finally turn out great and it actually did! I decided to add 1/4 cup of flour because it's so hot and humid here in the Philippines. I chilled the dough for 4 hours, scooped little balls using an ice cream scoop, put them in an airtight container, and then I put them in the freezer overnight. I baked them using only the bottom heat and I got the perfect cracks that I want. This recipe is so great and they are absolutely yummy! Kinda like a brownie. I will surely make this again and again and again and again...... Haha

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are my FAVORITE cookie! I've used this recipe for years now, unchanged, followed exactly as-is. Love it! I think some helpful tips are: 1. Use two spoons instead of your hands to work the dough into a ball and plop into the powdered sugar. 2. Put the dough back in the fridge between bakes. 3. Put your pan in the fridge/freezer to cook it off before placing a new sheet of cookies on it. The cookies don't turn out well if the dough gets warm from your hands, the pan, or sitting out. Good luck!

country:

text:
My Chocolate Crinkle Cookies came out pretty tasty, but they were flat and did not have the nice cracks like they were supposed to.  I wonder if the egg size played the role here since I used extra large eggs and the dough came out lumpy and sticky even after overnight refrigerated.  I couldn't even form a dough ball with my hands as shown on the instructional video.  It was impossible to use ice cream scoop with this texture, so I had to use two spoon to drop the dough and roll them on powdered sugar one at a time.  And by the time I placed the last powdered dough ball onto the baking sheet, the powdered sugar on the first few dough balls on the baking sheet had already melted into the dough balls.  

When the first tray of cookies came out flat and had no cracks, I tried to chill the next tray of dough balls by placing them in the freezer for a few minutes in hopes that the dough balls would stay in shape and they wouldn't spread out so much or came out flat after baking.  I was wrong.  It still came out flat plus uncooked from the oven that I had to bake them twice.  This, probably because the dough was too cold.

I've been surfing on the way to "fix" this recipe and found that a lot of people suggesting adding a 1/2 ts baking soda to the recipe and rolling the dough balls on granulated sugar first before rolling them on powdered sugar, to keep the moisture from melting the powdered sugar.  However, no one mentioned the egg sizes.  I'd really want to make this cookies agai

text:
I made this recipe exactly as written and they came perfect!! Did put them in the refrigerator over night so they were good and chilled. This made for easy scooping. I also used Parchment paper. I sprayed a little Pam on the sheet , put the Parchment down and sprayed a little more Pam and they came off very easy. I did cooked them the whole 12 minutes and got a really nice crackle effect. I started using the small scoop but thought they were a bit big so I used about 3/4 - 1/2 scoop and liked the size better. Nice , fudged, soft center but not gooey! Will keep this recipe!!

Tri d this hoping it was the recipe my family loves but we were all disappointed. Too cakey ! Visited mom and looked at her old recipe card and found the trick: Instead of cocoa powder, melt 4 squares of unsweetened chocolate (microwave works) and add all ingredients to melted chocolate. Yum! Just like Mom used to make! Fudge and delicious!

Delicious and easy and definitely a kid-favorite Christmas cookie!  Like other reviewers commented, these are weird.  The consistency of the batter is somewhere between brownie batter and cold hot fudge topping.  It is very gooey in your hands when you roll it, but freezing it and putting back in the freezer between trays helps.  Otherwise, they are very easy to make and turned out beautiful and delicious.

text:
I made these following the directions as stated. They are very good. They are chewy, which we like and very fudgy as well. I did cook them on the second rack down from the top as suggested by another and they were done in 10 minutes and cracked perfectly. I used silpats on the cookie sheets to keep them from sticking and they worked fine. I removed the cookies after 2 minutes to a rack for cooling. They also freeze well so I made them in advance too.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were delicious!  Almost like flat chocolatey brownies!  I put the dough in the fridge for 20 minutes, then scooped with a small cookie scoop, rolled into balls while wearing gloves and then into the dish of powdered sugar.  Once I had 6 or 7 balls in the sugar I rolled them around and put them on the cookie sheet without shaking any sugar off.  I sifted my p. sugar first with I think gave them a thick even coating.  Baked them on parchment paper and had no problems sticking.  Will make again for sure.

country:
None
text:
These worked out okay, very sticky dough though, in fact, I added about 3/4 cup more flour to help make it stiffer, and that worked out fine. I used parchment paper on the pans, and the cookies turned out great and didn't stick and kept the sugar from sticking to the bottom of the cookies. They are very cholately, (not a word, I know), but very good. I used the Nestle's chocolate, and believe that takes some of the edge off the chocolate taste. I will make these again, especially for Christmas giving.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1027660.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies had a fudge like taste & had a nice flavor! ** A note about working with the sticky dough - Moonnoodle's review included this tip: "I put mine in the freezer for about 45 minutes & used spoons to scoop out the dough DIRECTLY into the powdered sugar. Once the dough was in the sugar, they were easy to handle & just plopped into a perfect circle onto the pan."  Also remember, you MUST either use Parchment paper or greased pans... or they WILL stick because of the powdered sugar on the bottom of the cookie. Another reviewer suggested this:  Instead of rolling them in powdered sugar, roll some in regular granulated sugar... then after they come out of the oven, put a Hershey's Kiss on top, then back in the oven for 1min 30 seconds.

text:
I'm not a huge chocolate fan, but this was the perfect blend of chocolate without the overbearing sweetness. I followed another reviewer's advice and put the dough in the fridge between scooping it onto the cookie sheet. I just dumped about 2 cups of powdered sugar in a medium bowl to swirl the cookie balls. Other reviewers stated that their cookies didn't have the nice crinkle effect. I wanted to make sure mine did. The instructions also stated to refrigerate for 4 hours. I only had time for 3, but it didn't  to matter in the end result.

I added 2 ounces of baking chocolate (melted) to the dough to increase the chocolate flavor.  This dough MUST be chilled thoroughly or it will be next to impossible to shape into balls.  Also, I rolled the balls lightly into granulated sugar and then into the powdered sugar.  This helped to keep the powdered sugar from melting into the dough.

text:
Love these! They're a delicious little combination of cookies and brownies, and fairly simple to make.

I found they "crinkled" absolutely perfectly when I gave them a generous coating of powdered sugar, then waited until about 3 minutes before they were done... and flattened each one a bit with a spoon (while still in the oven). Baked for 10 minutes total.

I also added a quarter cup of dark and white chocolate chips because some reviewers said they were bland. One of my new favorite cookies.

text:
This recipe was great! Crunchy on outside and chewy and fudgy on the inside. I froze my dough for 2 hours and kept it in the freezer between batches. I dropped my dough right into the powdered sugar, rolled in a ball, and then rolled it in more sugar. The first batch I cooked 10 minutes and they were a little underdone, still delicious though. The rest of the batches were cooked for 12 min and came out perfect. I only got 4 dozen out of this recipe. Will certainly make again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My daughter and I love these cookies. They are very messy though. I've made them with and without the Hershey kisses. Yummy either way. I didn't make any changes to the recipe but here are my tips;

1. definitely need to refrigerate the dough (I do it over night)
2. damp hands when rolling (it's very sticky & tenacious!)
3. coat dough balls with plenty of powdered sugar
4. I used my pizza stone, no need for parchment paper
5. I cooked them for 13 minutes, came out perfect.
6. Don't put back in the oven if you use the kisses

text:
Tried this recipe for the first time.  I followed the recipe exactly.  I did do a triple batch because I bake a lot of cookies for Christmas.  I let the dough sit overnight in the refrigerator and scooped it in balls, rolled them in powdered sugar and slightly flattened them.  I baked only one tray at a time in the oven and baked on a higher shelf, as suggested by someone else.  They cracked and baked perfectly.  I did use the pre-cut cookie parchment sheets, which made for an easy clean up.  You definitely don't want to overbake these cookies or they get hard.

bakelyn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make tons of these every Christmas because my cousins (and I have a lot of them) devour these by the plateful. So I've picked up a few things that personally work for me. Here are my tips: 

To prevent sticking, I make sure my cookies are completely covered in icing sugar and I rub the sheets down with icing sugar before putting the balls down too.

I recommend making the batter a day before the cookies are needed, and refrigerating over night or even longer. I double wrap the batter ball in saran wrap to keep in the moisture.

To get the icing sugar to actually stay on in a thick coat and to get a nice crinkle, I first roll the ball in regular granulated sugar before rolling it in icing sugar. To simplify the process, I get a spoon and wear a plastic glove. I spoon out a bit of batter, push it off into a bowl of granulated sugar with my gloved finger, roll it, take it out, then roll it in a separate bowl of icing sugar. I put the ball straight onto the sheets and bake for the minimal time- 10 minutes. Then I let the cookies cool until they are stiff enough for me to lift the whole sheet off and place on the counter so I can reuse the tray with a new sheet.

Not a professional, so if you don't agree with my tips, then just don't use 'em. Your call. Best of luck!

userID:
229177
Display Name:
BARBARA A.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are my number one requested cookie.  I lost my recipe and have searching for a really good replacement.  Most of what I've found produces a flat, crispy cookie without enough chocolate.

I want a real chocolaty taste  so I  made a slight change, adding  1/2 c. melted semi-sweet chocolate with the cocoa, sugar, and oil.  I also rolled them in baker's sugar before the confectioner's sugar.

These were almost perfect.  I'd like them to spread a little less, but they tasted so good.  Moist with just the right amount of chocolate.

It is super runny out of the mixer, so you absolutely must sufficiently chill the dough.  I put it in the frig overnight.   

I slightly wet my hands before rolling.  The dough stuck to my hand less and the sugar stuck to the ball better.  I also put the dough back in the frig between batches.  

 I rotate the sheet at the halfway point and found the baking time was more 15-20 mins.

I highly recommend this version.

country:
None
text:
This recipe is nearly exactly like one I have been trying to find from childhood. I live in a very humid climate, so will add my two cents: Divide the batter in two and leave half in fridge (I will do the freezer next time) until finished with first half.  Expect the sugar to sort of melt into the cookie.  I tried to compensate by rolling extra thickly in the sugar & while that did help, it also added an extra layer of sweetness that I did not like. I had an oddball bar of chocolate that I crumbled into the batter and will now make that part of the recipe.  Lastly,  run a spatula under the cookies very quickly or they stick.

None
country:
None
text:
Holy hotcakes these are good cookies! The prep is quite a pain as its time consuming to keep rinsing hands, rolling balls and then throwing mix back in fridge while cookies are baking, but man oh man it's worth it! I let the mix sit in the fridge overnight.  As others have said, keep hands moist to prevent a sticky mess. I would roll, throw the ball in a bowl with powdered sugar and then use a slotted spoon to roll it around and place on cookie sheet. I got 60 cookies, 55 after 5 disappeared into my belly. The balls were a bit over an inch and I cooked for 11.5 minutes. Perfection!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are awesome. The end result is going to be determined by the brand of ingredients used. I used Guittard cocoa powder.  White Lily flour (which has a higher protein content). Plugra butter. Nielsen-Massey vanilla. Chilled the dough overnight. Used a 1/2 tablespoon metal spoon dipped in confectioners sugar to scoop the dough. Rolled them in a bowl. Mine took 12 minutes. They will look like they arent cooked enough but will be. Let them cool on the cookie sheet. I covered my sheet with parchment paper. These were great. Don't use Hershey cocoa powder!

text:
At first I was sceptical about making these because of the reviews that had complaints about it tasting bland. I followed the recipe without making any changes. The only downside for me was the four hour chill time. I could've left it overnight but I woke up at 2 am just to bake them (weird right??). And I don't regret it one bit! I loved them!!! Especially when warm. I found it a bit too sweet so I'll cut down the sugar next time by maybe 1/4-1/2 cup. But other than that, it was great. I would definitely make it again.

text:
Delicious!  I followed the recipe and directions almost exactly and they turned out as they should have!  When I scooped the dough (using a cookie scoop) I put the ball of dough directly into the powdered sugar. I didn't roll the dough, other than rolling  it around in the sugar. It was enough because their shape was perfect!  I'm not sure why some had trouble with their cookies not cracking. The only reason I can think of is that maybe the dough wasn't chilled long enough?  Mine was in the fridge overnight.  They were round, just enough chocolate flavor, and they crinkled. Perfect!

text:
I found this recipe after a friend requested the cookie. It is easy to make the dough and I opt to refrigerate over night. I also drop the dough onto to parchment lined cookie sheets to be sure I have equally sized cookies, wash my hands to get the dough off and then I go back and shape the cookie dough by slightly rolling it in my palms before putting it in the powder sugar. I also bake them at 325 with convection turned on. So good!

country:
None
text:
The flavor was great (with 1 cup milk chocolate chips added), but the dough was really hard to work with. It was sticky even after chilling overnight. I ended up using a spoon to scoop, another spoon to scrape the dough off the first spoon, and a third spoon to pour powdered sugar over the dough so I could have a spot to touch so I could finish rolling it in the sugar. There was no touching the dough without being covered in it, and I certainly could not have rolled the dough in sugar after touching it - it would have turned into an even stickier mess.

text:
I have a similar recipe. When I make these, friends & family will be on my doorstep. My recipe calls for butter & unsweetened chocolate bars instead of oil & cocoa. The batter is pretty thick. It must be kept cold when you're making the cookies, too. The confectioners sugar seems to coat them better & it's easier to roll into balls as well. I make the cookies a little larger than this recipe & start checking them about 8 minutes after I put them in the oven. I take them out when they still look a little under done, like a soft brownie. The cookies will bake a little more on the baking sheets while cooling. This cookie is SOOO much better a little fudgey.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3054.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a lovely, brownie-like batter that lends itself well to modifications. I used Dutch cocoa, which made them dark and very chocolaty and took another reviewer's advice and did 1 tsp of vanilla and 1 tsp of mint extract. Super, super good! I had no trouble getting them to crackle. I made up the batter, left it covered on the front porch for about 4 hours, (the beauty of a MN winter...front-porch-as-refrigerator) and used my Tablespoon measuring spoon to scoop them out and into a bowl of powdered sugar. My boys were able to help by swirling the dough balls in the sugar, coating them nicely. Even my two year old was able to help. I found that 12 minutes left them chewy and moist in the middle, and 13 minutes left them dry in the center, but not in a bad way, just in a cooked all the way through thoroughly kind of way. Great recipe. It makes a TON of cookies, too. I got about 40 Tbsp sized cookies out of the batter. Don't be alarmed if the batter looks thin and cake-like at first. The chilling will firm it up and delicious things will happen!
Review:
Rating:
5

k

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
A go-to recipe for me--I've it at least 20 times as written except I don't usually have time to chill it the full 4 hours. 

Vegan friendly version: use water instead of egg (2 TBS in place of 1 egg is what I did) and coconut oil instead of veg oil for extra flavor.  You won't get that same pretty "crinkled" or "cracked" effect with this version.  They just flatten out instead.  If you roll them in powdered sugar before baking, the sugar will just soak into the cookie and it will look like you never did it at all.  So, I did not roll them in sugar beforehand but instead dusted them with powdered sugar using a sieve after they were cooled.

Requested every Chistmas! One cookie that is super easy to ship (very sturdy). A few minor suggestions. For those that are complaining about weak flavor - you must use great quality cocoa. And to top it off, I add 1 cup of mini chocolate chips for a perfect chocolately cookie!

userID:
1463132
Display Name:
Rachell Meredith Briggs
isPro:

1

4

87
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/82677.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this as a base recipe. I made a few changes to the recipe to give it a more chocolaty flavor:

on a double boiler, I melted 2 cups of dark belgian chocolate.....once melted, I blended it with 1/2 a cup of butter, then added 2 teaspoons of madagascar vanilla. I also added 1/8 teaspoon of chili powder for a kick (you don't taste it but your cookie will have a deeper flavor  :)) 

Next add 2 c of sugar, then your 4 eggs

I used 1 3/4 c of flour with 2 teaspoons of baking powder and the 1/2 teaspoon of salt...I sifted the dry ingredients together a few times before adding to the wet. 

Chill in the fridge for a couple of hours. Once out, roll your cookies into a ball with about an 1 1/4 inch in diameter and roll that sucker in powdered sugar....just completely dunk and roll. You'll get a nice crinkled look once you take them out of the oven. They should look like white powdery truffles before you bake them :) 

When it came to baking time, I would let the cookies bake for about 8 minutes...when they are underdone. This will make sure they stay insanely soft! Cool them on a wire rack and enjoy :)

None
country:
None
text:
Definitely more like a fudge brownie than a cookie. I only kept them in for 8 minutes on the second to top rack. After they set/cool, they are really gooey in the middle and taste like a super moist brownie. Like the other users said, I used a pan with Pam spray and made sure to get enough powdered sugar on them. Great recipe. I might try adding nuts next time (walnuts or almonds).

I made these last night and followed the recipe exact only I substituted 1Tsp peppermint extract for the vanilla. Husband & 2 grown kids love them! My only reason for 4 stars instead of five is because I rolled into 1" balls and they spread out so they are larger than the ones in the picture. Also I did stick the dough/batter in the freezer for an hour and I used parchment paper which all worked out fine! I will definitely make again!

text:
Things of note:
- the recipe is for 1" balls which makes very small cookies as they do not spread out
- the dough is very cake-y / moist / sponge-y FYI

Not necessarily bad things just different than I have had in the past. :-) 

Make sure you really press the balls into the powder well, leaving it chunky, so when they crack you have an opaque layer of white powder. They look a lot better that way.

I was so excited to make these based on all the positive reviews but I'm quite disappointed. They turned out beautifully, just like the pictures. I followed the advice of freezing the dough first and they were a breeze to make but they don't have much flavour. I had added a teaspoon of expresso powder in a preemptive effort to intensify the chocolate flavour and even put a chocolate chip on top but that wasn't enough sadly. I should have listened to "luckygirl". Now I'm trying to figure out how to salvage them...maybe use them for ice cream sandwiches...

If you do insist on making these, I suggest adding a cup of white or semisweet chips to the batter.

I followed the recipe exactly. I put them in the fridge for 5 hours and the dough was still very sticky.  I used a cookie scoop and they turned our huge and flat! I tossed that batch and made them half the size. They still spread and were huge, flat disks. I started putting the dough in the freezer between batches. This did help reduce the stickiness. I ended up using a teaspoon as a scoop and they were about the size of a nickel. They were normal size cookies, but still flat as a pancake!! They definitely didn't look like any of the pictures posted. I'm not sure what I did wrong. I definitely won't be trying this recipe again.

userID:
3634132
Display Name:
Kristy
isPro:

followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
278
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Change nothing! These are great and so beautiful. I followed other reviewers' advice to ensure they crinkle and make life easy. The tips consolidated: I chilled for 2 hours and was fine. Last 30 min in freezer. Put bowl back in freezer as each bath cooks. Only put one tray in oven at a time to keep heat evenly dispersed and ensure a great crinkle. Use a cookie scoop but not too big. If you drop cookies into small bowl with powdered sugar, it's sooo much easier. Toss them around to coat fully and place on the cookie sheet. Cook the full 12 minutes. Only cool one minute on the sheet so they don't stick to the wax paper. Thanks for the tips, everyone!! Will make over and over.

text:
I made the dough as directed (adding just a tiny bit of ovaltine) and froze the dough for about 45 minutes like other reviews suggested. I tried using a spoon to drop into the powdered sugar then rolling into balls, and I also tried rolling into balls first then coating in the powdered sugar. The first way wasn't as messy but the cookies didn't always stay in a ball very well. I didn't have parchment paper so I sprayed the cookie sheets with cooking spray. I did make most of the cookies too big and now I know they should be small, like the recipe says. Still very good though!

text:
I'm not a big cookie-baker, and wanted to make something chocolate, using cocoa, and ingredients I had on hand without going to the store. These were fantastic! Delicious , attractive , foolproof. I chilled the dough for 4 hours and it was still quite sticky to work with.  The solution was to dust my hands and the melon baller I used as a scoop with powdered sugar, worked perfectly ( with the help of a mini-spatula). i added crushed walnuts for a brownie type taste. Next time I want to add dried cranberries. Best right out of the oven while hot !

These cookies were delish! They were similar to brownies in fudginess, but were great nonetheless. The batter was a bit sticky, but I'm used to making truffles, so it wasn't a big deal for me. text:
I got 3 dozen cookies using a 1-tablespoon cookie dough scooper which I baked for 10-11 minutes. Make sure that the dough is COLD (freeze for 50 minutes) and coat with LOTS of powdered sugar (the chocolate color shouldn't be visible underneath). I scooped the dough and dropped it directly into the powdered sugar, then rolled the top and sides around. It has a moist, fudgey inside that my friends love and say taste like a brownie.

text:
This is my bf's favorite cookie and he was craving it really bad while overseas. Luckily the weather was pretty cool and the travel time was only 2 weeks so I took the chance of shipping it off to him. I have never tried or made a crinkle before so had no idea what it was supposed to taste like (aside from being chocolate-y). I only made half the amount and got almost the full 3 dozen out of it. However they were tiny and very round (puffy)- not flat like in all of the pictures. The directions didn't say if I should flatten it after rolling it into a ball. Still, maybe that's just common knowledge and I missed it. But it still tasted great. I might even like it better this way because it has a very moist center. My bf claimed they were delicious and ruined his diet. Best compliment ever!

text:
Fantastic recipe. I used parchment paper of which I sprayed with Pam Butter Spray which eliminated any problems with them sticking! As others wrote..keeping dough in the freezer for 30 minute did the trick.(We are all pressed for time so I skipped refrigeration. They went right to the freezer. Only take out chunks at a time to work with and make sure your hands have water on them and the cookies will be super easy to work with!Also ..use the 2nd to top baking rack as someone else posted. PERFECT RECIPE!!!!!!!!

I didn't have any difficulty working with the dough, following directions exactly.  I prepared the batter in the morning and refrigerated until afternoon, and it was easy to work with.  The cookies are rich and fudgy.  I brought them to a Christmas potluck at work and they were all gone in very short order, and I was asked at least once for the recipe.  The only thing I would say is that they don't make 6 dozen, mine turned out closer to 4 dozen.  But they are delicious, and I will be making again!

Made this for the first time as the cookie for our cookie swap at work.  Made it exactly as the recipe states except followed other members with freezing for 30 - 45 minutes instead of putting the dough in refrigerator.  As I made the cookies I put the dough back in the freezer to keep it kind of stiff.  This made it easier to work with.  I also took the advice of the second shelf down from the top of the oven and baked exactly 10 minutes.  Came out perfect. I do want to try the peppermint extract next time.

text:
This is a very easy and versatile recipe.  I can't quite understand why so many reviewers had trouble with the texture of the dough--as long as it's cold, it's not hard to work at all. (Try the freezer if it's still too messy to form into nice balls.)  
I changed the recipe a bit by adding two teaspoons of coffee flavoring and one of vanilla, and it turned out great----and even better after a day or two.  Next time, I'm going to add peppermint flavoring and put Hershey's peppermint kisses on it for a holiday party. I'll be keeping this one!

None
text:
I made these exactly as directed. I used Hershey's brand cocoa powder. I used a tiny ice cream scoop, to make smaller cookies. Once they baked, cooled, and set, they were about 1.5" in diameter. 350 for 10 minutes was perfect for the small cookies. I also made a batch with a 1.5 tablespoon scoop, and those were best baked at 350 for 12 minutes. Since these are super rich, I think I will stick with the smaller size.

text:
Very good and easy to make!  I chilled the dough in the frig for close to 5 hours and didn't have too much trouble with sticky dough.  I would fill one cookie sheet and then put the rest of the dough back in the frig while the one pan baked.  I added one teaspoon of peppermint extract, as per other reviews and I am glad I did.  It was just a hint of peppermint, not too over powering.  I plan on making this recipe again and again.

This recipe was so easy to make! I did use vegetable shortening instead of vegetable oil but they were still AMAZING! And I put the batter in the freezer for an hour like other reviewers. 
The only thing I would do differently is make the cookies smaller. They are wayyyyyyyy too dense to eat a whole big cookie(I used a large ice cream scoop... I wanted huge cookies). 1 inch diameter cookies are more practical for this recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone loved these!  Once the dough was chilled, I used my cookie scoop to drop the dough, 3 at a time, into a small bowl filled with 1.5 cups powdered sugar.  I just swished the bowl back and forth to coat them, didn't shake off too much excess, and put them on a parchment-lined baking sheet.  Easy, no mess, and 10 minutes later, we had delicious fudgy cookies.  I made these with my chocolate-loving son in mind, so I added 1/3 cup mini chocolate chips.  Great with a glass of milk :).

These are a favorite in our household as well as the office! For those that complained that the cookies were plain or tasteless, that would depend on the quality of cocoa that you used. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these today and they were divine! :) A few things I discovered while making crinkles:

1. Make sure you roll the dough into balls quickly because at room temperature it absorbs the refined sugar so it won't be as white as snow and perfect. Also, it's messier because it will stick to your hand or to the spoon when you make the balls.

2. I agree that to get it to crack, place it on the top most shelf of your oven. Makes it crinkle perfectly.

I don't know if it's the temperature of the dough but my first batch were rounder than the second ones because the dough was still cold when I rolled them.

text:
This recipe has become one of my standards. I double it, then put half the dough in the freezer - its so nice to have if I need a quick dessert to bring somewhere later. Definitely use a scoop to put the dough into the powdered sugar - saves time and prevents some of the mess. I've also learned to make the powdered sugar covered balls ahead of time to store in the fridge for a day or two, then throw onto the cookie sheet to bake when needed.

userID:
8268566
Display Name:
OhioBecca
isPro:
False

0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used country-market farm fresh large eggs.  I used Hershey's Special Dark Cocoa.  
The recipe as shown made 8 dozen (not 6 dozen).  A 1 inch ball is really rather small.  My melon scoop was too large.  The balls spread out to about 2 inches.  No need to press them to help them spread out.
The dough is very soft.  It reminded me of soft-ball stage candy.  I wouldn't make this with young children helping.  It takes a long time to form the balls and prep for the oven.  I spent about 3 hours setting up trays and baking. I used cooking spray on my spoon and my fingers when I formed the individual cookies.   
Roll each cookie in ordinary white sugar and then roll in XXX sugar.  If you don't, the oil in the cookie will absorb the XXX sugar and it will disappear.  The white sugar keeps the XXX sugar on the surface.
These were beautiful and tasted much like brownie edges--crispy and soft at the same time.  
For Christmas I would add pepperment extract.
Review:

text:
My family loves this recipe.  It was easy and I found that we had most of the ingredients at home.  However I did tweak it a bit.  I did a half a cup of unsweetened cocoa powder mixed with a half a cup of special dark cocoa powder.  It doesn't change the calorie count or the fat count, but it does the sodium a little bit.  I also didn't wait for the cookie batter to cool for four hours and they still turned out ok so if you are turned off by the time just skip that step.  

Again, LOVE THEM!

text:
I tried this recipe twice in one week. The first time was a test run before a fancy dinner I was cooking. The cookies were good but just ordinary chocolate cookies. The second time I made the batter thicker ( a lot thicker) and they turned out perfect! very rich and chocolatey goodness. I only made one change- I subbed about a qaurter of the all porpose flour for all purpose chocolate flavoured flour. So, I'd advise anyone who this recipe didn't work for once to revaluate what went wrong and try again becuase they are an easy effort with a great outcome!

text:
Ooey, gooey goodness.  I made 1/2 a batch, but only ended up with 26 cookies, so I wish I had made a full batch, especially because these are for a party for tonight.  Now I won't get to keep a reserve at home for a late night snack.  These are like a powdered sugar covered soft brownie.  The dough was sticky, even after 4 hours of chilling, so I just dropped it from my cookie scoop right into the sugar, which made it a lot easier to work with.  Baked the on a Silpat sheet, so there was no sticking and easy clean-up.  Will probably make these instead of brownies because they turned out so fabulous!

text:
Very good cookie.  The flavor gets a bit bland for me after a while (but I'm like that because I like texture changes ie. nuts etc...in my cookies), so I made a few changes...that are not for the light eaters...I used 1 stick (1/2) cup of melted butter instead of vegetable oil.  I also put semi-sweet chocolate chips in it, for some surprise in the bite.  It is so chocolaty that you may not be able to handle it, but I am a fan.

text:
My family really loved this cookie.  I did add 1/2 c bittersweet chocolate to intensify the chocolate taste and that worked out well.  After making the first tray and seeing that they really didn't spread as much as I thought they would, I took a glass with a flat bottom and pushed them down on the other trays.  Big mistake!  We called those the ugly cookies.  At that point, it was too late to fix them.  The only other thing was for me, these dried out too quickly.  I like a moister cookie and after a few days, I just didn't like them as much.  Still a hit with everyone though!

userID:
4136590
Display Name:
Cookingfor5
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the second time I have made these and they are a hit... normally I don't like to use vegetable oil because it makes cookies too greasy but it seems to be fine in this recipe. It could be because since I am at altitude, I added about 1/2 c more flour for a chewy cookie. I also made them this time with drinking chocolate with sugar included since I was low on cocoa powder and it turned out great, simply a little sweeter. i think this could be done with any cocoa mix as long as the sugar was adjusted accordingly. They end up moist and keep well for at least a week (if they last that long). Chilling the dough for at least 30 min in the fridge is a big help and makes it much easier to roll into balls. I also use the other reviewer's tip about cooking on the top rack, they crackle beautifully. Thanks!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
Excellent.  I added about 1 1/2 tsp of instant coffee crystals to the sugar mixture and let it dissolve a bit before adding the dry ingredients, (thats just something I often do to chocolatey goodies being a coffee-a-holic.)   Also I left this in the refrigerator overnight because I have found that cookies always taste better if you let the batter rest a bit.    These were excellent cookies, aside from those small changes I made for our taste, I followed the recipe exactly.  Beautiful cookies too!

text:
These are great cookies!   The dough was very sticky, even after chilling for a couple days, so I simply dropped a spoonful of dough in a bowl of confectioners sugar, rolled it around in the sugar and THEN rolled it into a ball.  Worked great, and my hands weren't covered in sticky dough.  I also added 1 cup of mini-chips into the dough, the only change I made.  I will definitely make these again!

text:
A couple of notes on this one after reading the reviews:  I am impatient, so I only chilled the dough for maybe 20-30 minutes, and didn't have problems rolling it.  It was a little sticky, but not impossible.  Also, as far as the cookies sticking to the sheet, I just left them to cool on the sheet, and they popped off with a little push on each of them, so no issue there, either, and no waste of parchment.  I thought these were a really good chewy/ brownie like cookie.  Next time, I'll may add some chocolate chips for a little more depth or take some of the other reviewers' advice and add mint, probably crushed candy cane since i don't keep mint extract on hand, then finely crush some candy cane and mix it with the powdered sugar before rolling.  I bet those would be great for Christmas!

text:
Added these to my cookies trays this year after all the wonderful recommendations over on the recipe exchange board.  Kept dough in fridge over night and it was indeed sticky to work with but I coated my hands in powdered sugar and that worked wonders.  Have to admit after all that I was worried how well they would go over but they went over GREAT!  Hubby is not a big sweet eater but even he was raving over these.  He took a plate of them to work and everyone agreed they were a hit.  Will make again. Thanks for the recipe!  Edit:  Made this again for 2010 Christmas and found some great advice from another reviewer:  MS said to coat the balls in regular sugar to help the powdered sugar stick---worked like a charm!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been using this site for a few years, but I've never commented or rated a recipe until now. These cookies were absolutely delicious. I made them for a holiday party and they were the biggest hit. I made the batter exactly as the recipe states and, at the suggestion of other, froze the batter for 45 minutes. I used a samll scooper to scoop the dough and drop it directly into the confectioners sugar. It is a waste of time to try to handle the dough with your fingers. I I suggest HEAVILY coating the cookies with the confectioners sugar before placing them on a greased cookie sheet. Yes, you MUST grease it. I cooked 1 sheet at a time on the top rack of the oven to get them to look crinkled and they did. I will most definitely be making these little bites of heavenly chocolate brownie-like gems again. You will NOT be disappointed.

text:
My son says these taste just like brownies so if you don't need a cookie just make brownies.  If you really want a cookie then these are good.  When you are rolling the dough into little balls, divide the dough into quarters and only use 1 quarter at a time.  Keep the rest of the dough in the refrigerator until you need it because the colder it is, the easier it is to work with.

text:
These are fabulous!  I mixed them yesterday and baked two trays worth.  The dough stayed great overnight and I was ale to bake the rest this AM with no problem.  The dough is sticky, but if you have a cookie scoop it was no problem.  I just dropped the scoop directly into the sugar and didn't use my hands until the sugar was on the dough.  I coated really well with powdered sugar and baked on the 2nd to top rack in the oven.  They cracked beautifully and the taste is wonderful!  A keeper for sure!

text:
These cookies are festive looking and taste like a brownie. The only change I made was to add a square of melted bittersweet chocolate to the batter. I did what the other reviewers mentioned and put the batter in the freezer for 45 minutes so they were easy to handle and baked them on the second shelf of the oven one tray at a time so they would have a nice crackle on top. Unfortuneatly doing these steps made this recipe a little time consuming to make. I gave this recipe three stars because I felt it would be easier to make brownies in tiny muffin pans and douse them with powdered sugar.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are great, if not a bit sweet for my liking. I cut down the sugar by 100 grams although I would cut it down next time by 150g instead. I put the dough in the freezer for 1 hour and rolled them into balls using wet hands. I clean my hands every second or third cookie and to coat them I got a round bottomed rice bowl of 11cm diameter and put in the icing sugar. Then I put in the ball and quickly swirled the bowl. The cookie quickly becomes coated evenly and rounded very well. No mess at all. Remember to dig up the icing sugar after each cookie as it can form a compacted shell.

userID:

Display Name:
pomplemousse
isPro:

382

2015

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/58080.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very much like brownies!  I don't think there is a need for anymore chocolate--these are extremely rich as is.  The cookie dough is almost like a cake batter, so it's essential to refrigerate or freeze long enough to thicken it.  I made the dough last night and this morning made the cookies.  I used my medium cookie scoop (only bc my small scoop is dirty) and it worked well.  The dough is still pretty sticky, so rolling in sugar really helps.  I just rolled all the balls and then refrigerated until I could place them on my cookie sheets.  I have silpat mats and they still stuck slightly--it's best to let them cool on the cookie sheet for a while.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I didn't have too much trouble with this recipe.  I froze half the recipe in my large bowl for an hour, and transferred it to the refrigerator for an additional hour.  I used my tablespoon to scoop the batter and used my finger to drop it into the sugar, where it was easier to form into balls in the process of adding sugar.  I agree with the other reviews that you must coat the pan well, and completely smother the cookie in sugar to achieve the crinkling effect.  The only downside is that I felt the cookie only tasted okay.

Brownie like cookies.  I used a mini scoop and this recipe yielded 40 cookies that are about 2 inches wide.

My biggest suggestion is to put the dough in the freezer for 45 minutes instead of the fridge for 4 hours.  

Delicious, moist brownieish, crinkled just like in the pictures.  Fairly easy to make but just a bit time consuming.

My sister and I are in love with the chocolate crinkle cookies that our mall cookie store sells.  I stumbled on this recipe two years ago and decided to surprise her.  Aside from doubling the recipe, I follow the directions exactly.  They are wonderfully moist (rich, gooey, chocolatey brownie flavor), keep nicely in an airtight container on the counter, and crinkle beautifully.  I have been making cookies from scratch for 35 years, and hands down, these are my favorite!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/353265.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are one of my Christmas baking favorites! Only a few comments... the only way that this recipe yields 72 is if you make them bite sized...which I do quite often for my trays (I like to try a "little" of everything!).  So I use the small Pampered Chef cookie scoop, follow the recipe except bake only 8 minutes...this gives them that chewy center that I like!  Definitely a 5 star recipe! Update:  Last few years have had trouble with cookies not flattening, staying in a ball shape.  If I flatten before rolling in powdered sugar and only bake 9 min. (using the medium Pampered Chef cookie scoop).   Also let dough set out of fridge for a while helped too.

text:
Delicious, soft and so chocolaty!  I made this dough on a Friday but because of a heat wave in NY I didn't bake them until the following Monday (there was no way I was turning on the oven in 100 degree heat without AC:))  Regardless to the delay the were OUTSTANDING!  The dough was surprisingly very easy to handle when dropped straight from refrigerator into sugar - maybe the 3 day gap helped?  Also I did not use parchment paper but just sprayed the pans well with olive oil - they came right off no problems.  Crinkled beautifully and I really had to struggle to get some into the freezer before they all got eaten up.  Enjoy!!

text:
Awesome cookies!!  These taste just like brownies.  My husband (who is not a big eater) has declared that he could eat 1,000 of them. :)

I did not have any trouble with the stickiness of the dough.  Our freezer has a "jet freeze" setting, and I put the dough in with the jet freeze for about 45 minutes.  If you get your hands slightly damp before rolling the dough in your hands, that will help, too.

I made fairly small cookies and still only ended up with about 70% of the stated yield.

country:
None
text:
This recipe came out pretty good. The texture was a bit different than regular cookies - it had a bit of a cake/brownie quality to it. I had made several changes to the recipe: Instead of solely using vegetable oil, I used 2 tablespoons of butter and 3/4 tsp of oil. Additionally I chilled the batter in the freezer over-night. When rolling these cookies, I recommend that you work quickly - if the dough warms, it becomes mushy. The presentation is very pretty though!

CAMMYSAUCE

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/31309.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE crinkles, and these came out moist and chewy.  I made only one change... instead of refrigerating the dough, I made a "slab," wrapped it in plastic wrap, and popped it in the freezer while I cleaned up my mess in the kitchen.  I waited about 1/2 an hour and it was perfect to use a medium size scoop. 

A word of caution... you might think they're underbaked when you pull them out of the oven at 10 minutes, but you'll OVERbake them if you leave them much longer.  I (accidentally) left a sheet in for just under 12 minutes and you could definitely tell a difference in texture.  The next time I make these, I'm thinking I'll add shaved Andes Mints into the cookies for a little twist!

text:
These cookies were very good.  I used shortening in place of the margarine because I didn't have time to chill the dough.  They turned out nicely, but with using the shortening, they retained their ball-shape so I flattened the cookies with my hand after this discovery.

text:
If you're having a chocolate fit, these will work but....  They didn't seem chocolaty enough for me.  Next time I think I will add mint extract and dip them in chocolate (like the girl scout cookies).  I chilled the dough, rolled them in logs, covered them with plastic wrap and froze them.  Then when they were frozen I pulled them out and cut cookies off.  It was much easier then the directed way (I tried that way too!)

text:
I over-baked my first batch which turned out tough. So, I carefully monitored the next few batches. These cookies turned out chewy and yummy! Anyway, I had a problem about its appearance, though. It didnt get those "cracked" tops, which a normal cookie crinkle would look like. I just got a plain, round, normal-looking, chocolate cookie. But, anyway, these tasted great!! Oh, and eventhough I left the dough overnight in the fridge, it was still too sticky and hard to handle...
